TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Isabella Plains Catholic Secondary School: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows that:
1. They are concerned that in the Tuggeranong Valley area of the A.C.T., non-government schools have Year 11 and 12 places.
2. They want the new Catholic secondary school to be built at Isabella Plains to go to Year 12.

The petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensure that adequate resources are provided by the Government to allow year 11 and 12 places to be provided at the Catholic Secondary School at Isabella Plains in accordance with the Government's commitment to a dual system of education and greater school retention to Year 12.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Health Promotion Foundation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned,
(i) are alarmed that many sporting, cultural and community groups have been made to feel that they can attract sponsorship only from promoters of unhealthy products;
(ii) call for a National Health Promotion Foundation to be established through an increase in tobacco excise of 10 cents per packet; and

(iii) urge that the National Health Promotion Foundation provide national sporting, cultural and community groups with alternative sponsorship funding so that these groups can flourish without the taint of accepting money from tobacco companies and assisting in the promotion of their unhealthy products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators McMullan (from 100 citizens) and Reid (from 100 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes: Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and senators assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out that aged and disabled people who require accommodation and support in nursing homes are entitled to the highest possible standard and quality of nursing care.

We, the petitioners, request the Government to ensure that provision of funds for nursing homes in Victoria is sustained at least at a level sufficient to maintain the high standard of care now available in nursing homes in this State.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That the constitution of the Commonwealth has served Australia well, is not out of date, has proved to be flexible and should not be radically altered.

2. Our deep concern that the recommendations of the constitutional commission and its advisory committees which propose radical changes to the constitution are threatening to reduce our rights as citizens of the Commonwealth.

3. Our strongest opposition to any referendum proposals of the Hawke Government which gives more power to the government and less to the people and which concentrates that power in Canberra at the expense of the states and weakens the role of the Senate.

PETITION.TITLE: Release of Confidential Medical Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:

That we express grave concern about the public release of confidential medical information by the Government, sufficient to enable the public identification of Doctors and their patients and calls upon the Parliament to censure all those involved in this gross abuse of the privacy of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Elector-Initiated Referenda
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

that while having some reservations on individual aspects of the Constitutional Initiative (Electors Initiative) 1987 your petitioners wish to express our strong support for the concept of people's democracy implied in that Bill.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will

Refer the above mentioned Bill to an appropriate Parliamentary Committee and will examine the operation of direct democracy procedures overseas with the intention of passing legislation granting such facilities to your petitioners during the Bicentennial year.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth
That the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service.
That the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia.
That the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators MacGibbon (from eight citizens), Patterson (from 159 citizens) and Vanstone (from 30 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Preservation of the Environment: Referendum
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

But for a High Court decision narrowly favouring the Federal Government, 20,000 years old archaeological cave sites near the Franklin River, Tasmania, would have been destroyed, like a United Kingdom Government unable to stop a Wiltshire authority from clearing Stonehenge for a freeway. Constitutional protection for historical and environmental assets is needed.
Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government
To hold a referendum to amend the constitution so that:

The Federal Government has the bounden constitutional duty, which any citizen may legally require it to perform and a right superior to state and local governments, to set above the commercial advantage of one generation, protect and restore all we hold in trust for the future-
Including relics, sites, features, areas, wildlife, buildings or things of Aboriginal and other historical, cultural, architectural, scientific, aesthetic, ecological or environmental importance and-

To care for the maintenance of the balance of nature, manage land, marine and atmospheric use so as to avoid their degradation and act nationally and internationally in any matter seen as related to these including-

To prevent military and commercial use of uranium and derivatives, beach and related mining; to preserve Heritage Areas, The Great Barrier reef Region at least as originally defined in the 1975 Act and extended into Torres Strait.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Casino: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the proposal for the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra or the Australian Capital Territory.
(2) That a casino in Canberra would detract from the unique character and status of our National Capital.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to reject any proposal for or legislation which would permit the establishment of a casino in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your humble petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Retirement Payments
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in spite of many petitions and other communications, we are dismayed and disgusted at the lack of will on the part of the Parliament to restore to retired Commonwealth Public Servants and Defence Force Personnel, pension benchmarks which were affected by a two percent discount as part of the budget brought down in 1986.

Having regard to assurances given by the Government that the base will be restored, your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, act to ensure that this is done without further delays so as to remove the permanent and compounding effects of this discriminatory action taken under the guise of the entire community sharing the economic burden.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Judeo-Christian Values
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are concerned that the Judeo-Christian moral values which have been fundamental in our laws and education systems since the foundation of the country are now being undermined in the current practice of law making, and we are concerned that the values of the secular-humanistic philosophy have taken their place therefore jeopardizing the moral climate of our society and contributing towards immorality and violence in our society.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate for the restoration of Judeo-Christian laws and moral values.

Express concern over the further delay until 28 April 1988 of the Report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material.

That money has gone to the Monash Bioethics Centre, the director of which holds the view that not only do human embryos and human foetuses have no inherent right to life but also that even the newborn human infant has no inherent right to life. I want to ensure that next time this matter is raised at the Estimates Committee, the particular officers are there. If the Department is going to hide behind the National Health and Medical Research Council and it is going to pass it on to the Medical Research Ethics Committee, let there be an officer from both the National Health and Medical Research Council and Medical Research Ethics Committee present as well as the appropriate officer in the department. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment on local government funding. I intended to do so yesterday during the discussion of Government Papers. The report from the Local Government Grants Commission in New South Wales has come out and shows this Government's lack of funding to local government. It is the third or fourth report from the Local Government Grants Commission. The Government has been telling local government that it is better off but, in fact, it is evidence of the big con job that is being perpetrated on local government. The report shows that funding in New South Wales dropped by something like $5m over the last year and that follows a 10 per cent cut in funding to Tasmania over two years and a 6.3 per cent cut in local government funding to Western Australia. I believe the only State that increased its funding was Victoria-by $8m. The Local Government Grants Commission in Victoria distributed the funds in such a way that it looked like half of the local government councils of north-west Victoria were going to the wall or would have to increase their rates by 50-odd per cent. They had to go back to the larger councils in Victoria and ask them for help to send some of the extra funds that they had received back to the country.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a lot of talk about local government over the last couple of days, particularly by the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) yesterday. She implied that some members on this side of the House are sitting a bit uncomfortably about local government and the question of what will be debated next week on constitutional recognition. I think that people in the community who are involved in local government should realise what has been happening with funding. If we look at some of the figures we find that under the Fraser Government back in 1981-82 and 1982-83-and that followed increases in the personal income tax sharing-local governments were getting a regular amount of 2 per cent. Since the Hawke Government has come to power there has been an erosion of those funds: in 1985-86 to 1.9 per cent; 1986-87 to 1.85 per cent; 1987-88 to 1.75 and this year to 1.66 per cent. I think that local government would be more interested in that than in this token matter that is coming up next week about recognising local government.

When the Minister was asked yesterday what it meant, she said, `It recognises local government'. That is all she could say. I think that people on this side of the House are more interested in recognising local government in the terms that applied under the Fraser Government when local governments were guaranteed a 2 per cent funding arrangement. I listened with interest when Senator Bjelke-Petersen and Senator Panizza spoke a day or so ago about road funding. That is really affecting local government. We have seen a 25 per cent, or $300m, drop in real terms in the last three-odd years. Road funding has been frozen at something like $1,245m since 1983-84. That has not changed. Victoria and the other States are ripping up sealed road and going back to gravel roads because of the funding cuts.

I think that this Government has a lot to answer for on local government funding. I referred earlier to the situation mentioned in the Local Government Grants Commission report. Honourable senators may remember a Prime Minister called Whitlam back in the days when general purpose grants commenced in 1974-75, when $56.3m was provided nationally under the scheme. Of the 196 local authorities in New South Wales, 22 local authorities did not receive any funding. They had to wait until Fraser became Prime Minister. In the tradition of support for local government that this side of the House has always given, the Fraser Government brought in the personal income tax sharing that I referred to earlier and made it possible for local government to get a fair deal. It was the first time that a government had provided every council with a grant. That is something that should be borne in mind.

The other thing the Fraser Government did was to link funds available for local government to the Commonwealth tax collections. Only since this present Government came to power have we had the erosion of funding to local government. I do not think local government will be hoodwinked by these cosmetic funding arrangements. The most important thing to remember is that under the Liberal Government local government received a fair share. I quote from the report of the Grants Commission in Tasmania:

. . . the Commission firmly considers that the previous basis of allocation has resulted in an equitable distribution of the funds, a distribution which has found the general acceptance of the great majority of local government authorities in Tasmania. However, the new principles of allocation prescribed in the Commonwealth Act, together with the desire for uniformity between States have led the Commission to the inescapable conclusion that significant changes would have to be made, notwithstanding the substantial effect on some existing grants. In this respect, the best that the Commission can do to cushion the fairly considerable loss of funds by some municipalities is to ensure that the new methodology is phased-in over as long a period as possible.

This has happened all over Australia. I am sick and tired of listening to representatives of local government saying how well this Government is looking after them. In fact, they are all receiving less money. They all believe that they are being looked after. The greatest hoodwink job that has ever been perpetrated on local government concerns quarterly payments. That has cost every State at least a 5 to 10 per cent drop in revenue. I conclude my remarks by saying that local government is not getting a very fair deal at all at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night when the Committee adjourned I was asking the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Bolkus, a few questions on the resident classification pro forma for nursing homes. I asked who the person was who invented this score sheet and what qualifications he had. I was told that it was a statistician with research qualifications and that it was done in consultation with 1,200 nursing homes. I asked the Minister whether he could give me the name of at least one nursing home that was completely in favour of the score sheet. I wonder whether the Minister can now give me that name.

—I am told that we are unable to give individual names because of some restriction under the Health Act. I am not sure of the nature of that restriction but hopefully I will get some further advice. Some of the comments that--
—I do not want some of the comments; I want the names.
—I cannot help Senator Walters with the names, and if she does not want the comments I will sit down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night I was told that 1,200 nursing homes were consulted on this score sheet and that they were happy with it. I do not want some of the comments. I want to be able to approach one nursing home that was absolutely in favour of the score sheet and its method. I have not found one nursing home that is in favour of it. The Ministers says, `It's all too complicated. We have restrictions. We can't tell you, Senator Walters, of one nursing home that is in favour of this score sheet. We did consult and they made very good comments. I can give you a whole lot of comments'. I do not want unsubstantiated comments. I want the name of one nursing home that is completely in favour of this ridiculous score sheet, which was put together by a statistician and researcher.

SPEECH.PARA: As a nursing sister, let me give the Minister some advice. I know from experience that if it takes two people to transfer a patient from a bed to a chair beside the bed, that is not very difficult or time-consuming nursing. But for that procedure the nursing home gets a score of 4.37. That score is given just for a patient being transferred from a bed to a chair beside the bed by two people. For a patient who is incontinent, with the incontinence occurring more than once daily, the score given is 1. Does the Minister realise what such nursing entails? It entails the nurse changing the full bed, with assistance-often two nurses are involved-several times a day, washing the patient in the process and taking considerable time to make that patient comfortable. And the score for that procedure is 1.

That is not all that occurs with such a patient. A patient in that condition would also need the prevention and care of pressure areas to avoid bed sores. Let us consider a patient who needs that care as well. If a patient requires attention for pressure areas one to three times a day, the score is 2.63. So for a patient who is incontinent and needs pressure areas done, the total score is 3.63. That involves considerable nursing care, over a considerable time, by more than one nurse or more than one trained sister. So the score is barmy. This is no justification for giving a score of 4.37 just for two people transferring a patient from a bed into a chair beside the bed and only 3.63 for nurses tending a patient who is incontinent and liable to get bed sores. Can the Minister please explain the reasoning behind that score?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can do is retail the account I have about the resident classification instrument (RCI) system which was developed through three trials, the last covering 1,200 nursing homes and 17,000 residents. A large number of directors of nursing have supported the new RCI, which is a vast improvement on the old system. The weightings to questions are derived solely from their assessment as to residents' relative service needs. Some people are still somewhat confused about the purpose of the RCI. It is not designed to be a care plan or time management tool; rather, it is the means by which national funding for nursing and personal care can be provided fairly and according to residents' needs. It has been developed to predict whether a nursing home resident has, on average, higher or lower service needs than other residents. Therefore, a score of 1 on incontinence and a score of 4.37 on transfers does not mean the treatment of incontinence requires a quarter of the time as does assistance with transfers. Rather it means, according to individual directors of nursing, that incontinence is a far poorer predictor of a resident's overall service needs than are, for example, transfers. The weighting simply reflects the capacity of each variable to predict service needs.

SPEECH.PARA: The major trial of the resident classification instrument showed that it has a 94 per cent accuracy level in predicting service needs in a nursing home as assessed by individual nursing home directors of nursing. The current ad hoc system has been shown to have only a 9 per cent accuracy level-hence the current inequities. I am afraid that I cannot contribute anything more to the debate than that. I hope Senator Walters will appreciate that there are certain limits to the extent to which one can have an extensive discussion of this sort of issue in the committee stage of an Estimates Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer the Minister gave obviously came from a statistician who has had absolutely no experience in the situation she is trying to research or gain statistics about. It is an absolutely hopeless answer. From a practical point of view, the answer is nonsense. I do not know why the Minister will not tell me the name of one nursing home that is happy with the scorecard. He will not give me one. He just says, `We cannot do that. It is all very confidential'. But he cannot do it because there are not any such nursing homes.

SPEECH.PARA: I have approached a number of nursing homes, not one of which is happy with the scorecard. All of them say to me that the whole thing is rubbish. They say to me, `Have a look from a practical nursing point of view'. They say that this matter is associated with the grant for the costs of a nursing home. The Minister is telling me that it has nothing to do with nursing hours. I find the Minister's answer completely unsatisfactory. It is the answer that any researcher or statistician would give and certainly is not an answer that a practical nurse or director of nursing in any nursing home could possibly abide by. The Minister says that the Government has consulted 1,200 nursing homes, yet he still refuses to give me the name of one nursing home. I asked Senator Bolkus last night for the name of one nursing home. He assured me that he would give me that. The Minister this morning tells me that for various reasons, all sorts of confidentiality and so on, he cannot give me the name of a nursing home. I just do not believe that he has one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to return to the matters Senator Calvert was raising on local government. The allocation for the 1987-88 financial year was based, according to the report of the Commonwealth Grants Commission, in New South Wales at least, on an expectation of an inflation figure of 8 per cent. It was then said that this figure would be adjusted for the actual increase in the consumer price index for the 12 months to March 1988. As I understand it, that figure is now 6.9 per cent. Does that mean that local governments will have to pay back money they have already received from the Commonwealth? If so, what is the mechanism under which that will be done? I also ask why on earth the forecast figure of 8 per cent was given when, at the time, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was forecasting a 6 per cent inflation rate-which of course has not been reached. It has blown out beyond that and I think it is almost 6 per cent for the three quarters.
—It is 6.9 per cent.

—The annual rate is 6.9 per cent, as I understand it, for the 12 months to March. But, as I was saying, for the three quarters so far of the current financial year, I think it is well over 5 1/2 per cent, clearly indicating a blow-out from the figure the Treasurer had mentioned, and is another example of lax economic management by this Government at a time when we should have been concentrating very heavily on maintaining the lowest possible inflation rate. This Government has set out on a different course altogether, taken the soft option, with the result that we are becoming more uncompetitive and our costs are rising at double the rate of those of our trading partners. That is a matter of major concern. It is interesting that here we have all these different expectations of an inflation rate depending on what the Government is doing. Here it appears that the Government wants to make a good fellow of itself by saying to local government, `These are going to be your grants based on an 8 per cent inflation rate', when in fact the inflation rate forecast in the Budget was 6 per cent and the final result will probably be about 7 per cent. I would like the Minister to let me know what is going to happen to that shortfall and whether councils have to pay the money back.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to note that the money was allocated this year on the basis of significant changes made as a result of a paper of principles prepared by the Commonwealth Office of Local Government and finally agreed to by the Commission. According to the annual report of the New South Wales organisation, copies of this paper were forwarded to the local government and shires associations and the Town Clerks Society for comment. The local government associations circularised their response to councils. The additional principles proposed by the associations to guarantee the grants of individual councils were not accepted by the Commission. The local councils themselves put up propositions to protect their own interests, naturally, and these were not accepted by the Commission. What interests me is that this has resulted in many councils getting what appears to be a raw deal this year. Perhaps the Minister at the table, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), could explain why he thinks it is not a raw deal. This raw deal was supported by the then New South Wales Labor Government Minister for Local Government and was submitted to the Commonwealth in March 1987.

The result of all these changes is that many councils in New South Wales have not received their 8 per cent inflation covering increase. On the contrary, many of them have done extremely badly. Some, for example Mudgee, are losing more than $40,000 of what should have been their rise. Kiama is losing about $26,000, Cooma-Monaro is losing about $60,000 and the Singleton council lost close to $50,000. In looking through the list of those that did badly I see strangely enough that so many of them appear in electorates which frankly would be far better represented in this place if they were represented by Liberals rather than the present Labor members. I refer to the seats of Calare, Eden-Monaro and Hunter. I find that the local members of these electorates have not been terribly successful in protecting the interests of the local councils in terms of Federal funding. For example, in Calare, the Blayney council was badly dealt with, and the Mudgee council and the Orange council are all falling well short of even an inflation indexed rise in Federal assistance to local government. In Eden-Monaro we have Bombala, Cooma-Monaro and Snowy River, and in Hunter we have Merriwa and Singleton. So it seems some councils have been disadvantaged. I would like the Minister's explanation of why the request from the local government association was rejected to protect the interests of local government? What will happen to the money, the 8 per cent, that may well have been paid out? Does it mean that these allocations, listed in these sheets of what are the 1987-88 grants to local government, will now be reduced? If so, will there be a revised sheet put out showing what councils really are getting, and do the councils have to pay the money back?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry. You didn't ask a question, I take it.

—The Minister obviously is paying great attention to this debate! I asked a series of questions during my speech. It is extraordinary that this Government takes so little interest in, and has so little concern about, the welfare of local government that the Minister involved is not even listening to a series of very clear and significant questions about whether local government councils have to pay back money that has been granted to them in the expectation of an 8 per cent inflation rate when it looks as though it will be about 6.9 per cent or 7 per cent. I also ask the Minister, now that he is listening, whether there will be a revised list of what the expenditures are. Will the Government advise us of that?

SPEECH.PARA: I also ask the Minister to explain the reasons for knocking back the request by the Local Government and Shires Association that the adjustments to be made to the method of payment this year be changed in order to guarantee the grants to individual councils. The Commission did not accept that request and the Government did not proceed with it. It did not protect the interests of these councils, the names of which I read out. I ask the Minister: Will councils have to pay back money that was paid out in the expectation of an 8 per cent inflation rate, when it does not appear that that will be the inflation rate for the year?

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise some matters compatible with those which I raised last year; that is, the level and competence of management of funds for Aboriginal communities. SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the Marra Worra Worra Aboriginal Corporation which is a group located essentially in Fitzroy Crossing in the north-west of Western Australia. It is probably best known because of its past association with young Stephen Hawke. I will give some background: The Corporation acts as a cheque cashing agency for the benefit of community members wishing to cash their social security entitlements. That is not an unusual procedure in itself. It is standard procedure for the Corporation to receive members' social security cheques through the mail, to prepare a listing of these cheques showing deductions to a community chuck-in-in other words, the money that is thrown in for general community use-and to provide a net cash payout direct to the member or through an agency of a community bookkeeper. In other words, money gets fed in in a lump sum and is then paid out in bits and pieces to those essentially entitled to it-to individual members of the community. The member does not sight or endorse the cheque or the listing. The procedures are open to abuse in that no internal control exists over the cash movements between the point of issue of cash from the safe of the Corporation to the community bookkeeper and receipt by the member. In other words, there is absolutely no discipline of bookkeeping or accountability of large amounts of cash from one point to another. Cheques cashed in that way for the last financial year amounted to $2.6m. The Corporation runs with a float, normally something in excess of $100,000. So on any one day there is in excess of $100,000 in cash sitting in the drawer or the safe of the Corporation. There is no discipline in the protection of that money. The Corporation has been unable to obtain insurance over the $100,000 float because insurers are totally dissatisfied with security arrangements. Cash is ordered on a weekly basis and is delivered without supervision or without proper security protection.

The cash movements are significant and give rise to concern as they occur without the protection of security procedures generally accepted as necessary. The concern applies to the safety and well-being of staff who handle the cash as well as the cash itself. I understand that this matter has been raised with the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Department of Social Security. To my knowledge, limited as it might be, no steps have been taken to rectify it.

I turn for a moment to the system of accounting. A control account was maintained for the cash float. However, the control broke down in February 1987 and by 30 June 1987 errors totalling $10,148 had occurred. In other words, there was a reconciliation of that $100,000 and there was a discrepancy of over $10,000 in respect of it. The float contained $10,148 more than it should have contained. Honourable senators might say that that is good accounting, but it is inaccurate accounting. A test of the float on 27 October 1987 revealed further errors totalling $26,239. In other words, the float was more than 20 per cent out. The accountants suspect that these excess funds belong to client communities, although the necessary analysis of float transactions has not been carried out to determine ownership of these funds. That is because the bookkeeping is just not sufficiently sophisticated to allow them to be traced properly.

The rules of the Corporation require that persons seeking membership of the Corporation be formally admitted by the governing committee. To the best of the knowledge of the accountant, membership of the Corporation is now quite uncertain. A register of members is not maintained and the legality of any resolutions passed at a general meeting would be in doubt. An annual general meeting of members, as required by clause 11.1 of the rules, was not held for the three years to 30 June 1987. The Marra Worra Worra Aboriginal Corporation received $2.6m just in cheques, putting aside grants. It did not have a meeting for three years and the membership was unable to be identified. Under clause 12 of the rules the governing committee must be elected each year at the annual general meeting. A committee member holds office for only one year.

The Corporation operated a trust account to receive and disburse income tax refund cheques on behalf of members. The books of account were not properly maintained, resulting in a shortfall of trust funds totalling $8,859 which was made good from Corporation funds. The Corporation received a grant of $52,970 in 1985-86 under the community employment program to establish an Aboriginal traditional arts centre. At the completion of the project $10,549 of grant funds had been expended for non-grant purposes. The Department of Employment, Education and Training wrote to the Corporation requesting a refund of these moneys. Representations have been made seeking that the debt be waived but a contingent liability, not disclosed in the balance sheet, exists to the extent of $10,549.

The Corporation failed to issue group certificates to all employees as required under the Income Tax Assessment Act. A contingent liability, not disclosed in the balance sheet, exists to the extent of penalties which may be incurred. The accountant is unable to ascertain what those penalties might be. The Corporation operates in an air-conditioned office situated on land excised from a lease reserve held by another Aboriginal corporation. A sub-meter at the office was read on 15 December 1987, showing that 76,130 kilowatt hours had been consumed since installation-date uncertain. At an average rate of 12.16c per kilowatt hour the cost of that consumption is $9,257. A contingent liability, not disclosed in the balance sheet, exists to the extent of electricity reimbursement due to that other community, but the amount cannot be ascertained without further research.

The Corporation purchased airline tickets on behalf of client communities and then obtained reimbursement. A contingent liability exists in this regard, although the amount has not been ascertained. The air fare expense account shows a credit of $5,797. The auditor was not able to substantiate by way of evidence the legitimacy of a payment of $8,000 by the Aboriginal Affairs Planning Authority in connection with expenses incurred in holding a meeting. Cheques totalling $7,208 written on the school administration bank accounts were not detailed and the cheque butts were lost. These payments have not been vouched.

The Corporation operates an artefacts enterprise under the name of Mangkaja Arts and Crafts. The auditor has not confirmed whether this name is registered. The financial reports of that group have not been consolidated with those of the Corporation. Allegedly, a separate entity is to be established. —I know they were extracts from the auditor's report. I am not trying in any way to minimise the importance of correct practices being employed by those who are the recipients of Commonwealth taxpayers' moneys. If they receive those moneys they ought to be accounted for in absolutely the proper way. I think it is important to say that the Government has been conscious of the sorts of deficiencies and problems that can arise with these communities as one attempts to--
—It is no good being conscious about it, Minister; you have to do something about it.

—I am coming to that, Senator. I put it in the context of bringing these communities to a stage of self-management and proper determination of their affairs in a way which exposes them to the necessity to account properly for the funds which Commonwealth taxpayers provide to them. I do not imagine that that is an easy process to achieve overnight. I recall during the Estimates Committee hearing that there was a discussion relating to the Aboriginal educational development program, which program has as its major thrust an attempt to make Aboriginal people exercising leadership and holding responsible positions in corporations, such as has been outlined by Senator Crichton-Browne, aware of the management practices and the requirements of running organisations which have such a lot of money flowing through their hands.

SPEECH.PARA: I am advised by departmental officers that 1,200 grants are made each year. There are difficulties with perhaps a dozen or so every year-the type that have been outlined by Senator Crichton-Browne. At the Estimates Committee hearing there was considerable discussion concerning some particular instances where the Australian Federal Police and corporate affairs bodies have been at work to try to unravel what did occur-Senator Crichton-Browne's concern about the auditor's report was that some matters were still unclear-and, where criminal activity has occurred, charges would be laid. The overall attempt to make sure that those in positions of responsibility understand managerial practices and bookkeeping requirements so that proper auditing of Commonwealth moneys can be undertaken, is a major thrust of the Aboriginal educational development program. I think the Commonwealth is discharging its responsibilities in a general sense in that regard.

In regard to the particular instance which the honourable senator has brought to the attention of the Committee, it is not as easy to deal with it in the Committee of the Whole as it was to deal with those particular matters which we discussed during the Estimates Committee hearing. But I undertake to refer those particular analyses of Senator Crichton-Browne to the Minister and ensure that they are followed up. I do not know whether the Corporation is incorporated under Western Australian law and subject to that Corporate Affairs Commission or under Commonwealth law and subject to our own agencies in that regard. I will make sure that Senator Crichton-Browne's remarks are followed up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night in the debate I raised several questions with regard to the announcement made by the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, on behalf of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, concerning the proposals to deal with the legislation for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission to kick-start and commence operations on 1 January next year. Included in that statement by the Minister was an undertaking that various elections would be conducted in Aboriginal communities in September, October and November this year.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like the Minister to address the following problem. In the absence of legislation coming before this Parliament detailing any form of guidelines before those proposed elections, will the elections proceed and be held without the legislation having been passed through this Parliament? Are the elections in any way to be complicated by the matters to be considered by the Australian population at referendum on 3 September? If the elections cannot proceed as originally announced, will this in effect mean that the new Commission will not start on 1 January?

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the elections can be conducted independently of the passage of the legislation, as was the case with the National Aboriginal Conference membership. That Conference was established under Prime Minister Fraser. Elections were conducted and the Conference membership was put together independently of legislation. It would be the intention that the legislation would validate the elections and the Commission could not operate except with the passage of the legislation. As to the question concerning the impact of referendum proposals, I really do not see the link that the honourable senator is trying to make.

—I will be more specific. Given that the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission will exercise many executive functions and, in effect, become a quasi-Aboriginal parliament, taking up many areas now covered by local government, how can the Government or the Minister in any way imply to this Parliament that the elections could proceed independently of the legislation being properly considered by the Parliament? I find it quite incomprehensible that the comparison is linked to the former Conference, which was merely an advisory body to both the Minister and former governments. An important point of principle is involved here. It is very obvious that the Government is not only showing a very high-handed attitude with regard to the constitutional referendums but also proposing a very major and significant change of administration of Aboriginal issues. It is proposing elections of a very convoluted form of regionalised councils, possible zones and many other forms that will effect the expenditure of some $700m per annum, and that those elections should proceed without the endorsement of this Parliament.

—In principle, this is not a matter of any great remark. I recall that in my portfolio legal aid advisory committees were established before the relevant legislation was passed by this chamber. It was understood that the actual appointments could be undertaken and they undertook their functions with the passage of that legislation. These elections will be conducted by the Australian Electoral Commission in the hope that the legislation will be passed by this Parliament in the Budget session. I understand that it is proposed to hold the elections in October, November and December in order to have the commissioners available to start work as a commission on 1 January. Of course, the Parliament may decide that it does not wish to pass this legislation, in which case it will not be able to operate as a commission. The actual election process will be undertaken in anticipation of that Commission being established.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to participate in the discussion on this item of the Estimates but, in the light of the extraordinary exchange which has just occurred between Senator Tambling and Senator Tate, I am bound to say that I am astonished by what the Minister has just said. I am not in the least persuaded by his analogy with the minor matter in his portfolio of a few years ago in relation to what he termed legal aid advisory committees. I suppose those committees were presiding over, if they were presiding over anything other than giving advice, spending amounts of about $1m or $2m-$4m or $5m at the most. As Senator Tambling said quite rightly, we are talking about executive authority for a body to preside over the spending of hundreds of millions of dollars. Senator Tambling cited the figure of $700m. Surely the Minister is not telling this chamber that the Government is prepared to countenance proceeding to elect a body to undertake functions of that kind without full and proper parliamentary procedure and process and the passage of legislation. He conceded that the legislation may even be rejected by this place. Surely he is not prepared to countenance that without that fundamental parliamentary process having been completed. I would like the Minister to reconsider the answer he has just given to Senator Tambling and consider whether he should not withdraw it and come back to the Committee with a more prepared statement-not necessarily today, because we want to get through these matters today; certainly, the Opposition does and, no doubt, the Government does just as badly. I believe that the Minister's statement cannot be allowed to pass and stand on the record without further supplementation.

—I add to Senator Stone's comments and ask the Minister to address the point of principle as to how and under what basis the Electoral Commission will conduct the elections. In the absence of regulations and any form of legislation for such an important body, how could we expect, in terms of credibility, not only the Government but also the Electoral Commission to conduct such an important range of elections around Australia? What would happen with appeals and courts of disputed returns? How would those things be established? If it were to be done by way of a series of ministerial guidelines on another proposed administrative arrangement, I believe that it would be insulting to the Aboriginal constituency as well as to the important points of principle that have been raised.

—I will take Senator Stone's advice and seek further clarification as to the machinery that might be put in place, but I must say that, as was stated by the Minister in the document dated 27 April which was tabled in the Parliament--
—Yes, we have read that document.

—Yes. All I am saying is that it is quite clear that the Government's intention is that those elections do take place in a way which enables the Commission to commence operations on 1 January 1989 should this Parliament pass the legislation during the Budget session. I am repeating what we all know. As to the actual machinery that will need to be put in place under the aegis of the Australian Electoral Commission, I do not have the details on how that process is to be conducted, but I will undertake to provide them to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister to the Wangkatjungka community, which is in the north-west of Western Australia. Did the Minister say that 12 out of 1,200 have caused problems?
—Well, I was advised about 12.

—I wonder whether anybody has looked under the carpet. Last year I raised a matter concerning the Oombulgurri group. The sad thing is that when an Aboriginal community loses $100,000, so does the surrounding community. The Oombulgurri group is situated across the gulf from Wyndham. That $100,000, by and large, came out of the pockets of local businessmen-the baker, the storeman, the greengrocer, the fuel agent and the Toyota agent. Those are the people who lost out. The Oombulgurri group was not able to pay those people. It is very hard for a small businessman in Wyndham to carry debtors owing $50,000 over six months. It is not only the Aboriginal community that suffers from incompetence but also the surrounding community.

SPEECH.PARA: I was in Wyndham two weeks ago. One of the problems that the Oombulgurri group had was the fact that it had decided to indulge itself by obtaining a barge to bring cattle across the gulf. To my knowledge, not one single beast was ever loaded. The barge was redesigned, at great expense, and it was never able to sail. The group ran it up on the shores of Wyndham and it sat there for the last 12 months. Two weeks ago it was pulled out of the water to see what could be salvaged and it was found that the two new beautiful engines that had been put in it had been lying submerged for the last 12 months so they were ruined. I raised the problems of Oombulgurri and that barge in this chamber 12 months ago. It was pulled out of the water two week ago. I wonder what other problems are not being pursued.
I refer to an auditor's report to members of the Wangkatjungka community. The audit was done on 24 November 1986. The report states:

It appears to have been the practice for your project officer, Mr. Peter Ross, to book up personal motor expenses to the Association when on visits to Derby. Mr Ross claims that he arranged with your accounting agents, Marra Worra Worra-
the group to which I referred previously-
to deduct these expenses from his wages. However, this was not done.

Is that a half reasonable way of running a business-that a man books up in somebody else's name and takes the benefit with some obscure word of mouth arrangement that the cost of those items should be taken from his salary? The association paid for two charter flights carrying Mr Ross to and from Derby on 2 May 1985 and 18 February 1986. The auditor has been unable to confirm that these expenditures were for the benefit of the association and were authorised by the committee.

The expense items under `Store Purchases' include various expenditures which do not relate to store purchases. These include food items used by Mr Ross in entertaining visiting officials and personal items for Mr Ross which Mr Ross maintains should have been deducted from his wages by the Marra Worra Worra but were not deducted. They also include supplies for homemakers, items of equipment for the project officer's house and 34 cartons of beer which Mr Ross informs the auditors were used to entertain visiting officials. I hope it is not a reflection of the indulgence of officers of the Department that 34 cartons of beer are required when they go to Fitzroy Crossing for a day to check on the books. This beer was allegedly also purchased to replace beer purchased by community members from Christmas Creek station but not paid for. Apparently, under `Store Purchases' was a deduction for payment for assistance in extricating a bogged truck.

Invoices for the supply of goods into store were often recorded simply as `groceries' with no details of the items supplied. Store purchase control, therefore, was impossible. This system is open to abuse. No control existed over store purchases or sales. The store enterprise showed a gross profit of only 8 per cent on sales. What conclusions can one draw from that? The auditor suggests that goods were paid for but not received, stolen from the store or not correctly paid for-and the moneys banked.

Concerning the generator, a detailed analysis of the use of generator fuel was carried out. It was found that consumption varied between 146 litres per day and 551 litres per day-the latter being during the cooler months of the year when airconditioning should have been at a minimum. The figures suggest that diesel fuel is being used for purposes other than generating electricity or that fuel paid for is not being delivered to the generator tank. Control was not kept over social security cheque cashing. The auditor was unable to reconcile moneys drawn with moneys rebanked-the difference was $7,168 for the year. Control was not kept over loans to community members. Loans of $10,909 simply were written off.

Wages records show that an amount of $180 per week was paid to Mr Alan Lawford, the powerhouse operator, during March, April and May. Mr Lawford was not residing at the community during these months. The auditor was informed that the powerhouse was operated by the principal of the Christmas Creek primary school during that time and a cash payment of $80 a week was also paid to him. It follows from the above comments that some consideration should be given to the process of authorising payments. I find that to be a classic understatement. The auditor found no indication of any formal process of authorising payments during 1985-86. That is just a report on one community-and I dare say it is not an isolated community.

The tragedy is that because the Government has chosen not to ensure that these communities are properly audited, managed and supervised, the Aboriginal community ends up suffering. Every time these matters come up, every time creditors at Fitzroy Crossing cannot get paid and have to go to their bank managers to beg and plead for a further overdraft, the antagonism, bitterness and ill feeling towards the Aboriginal community is manifested in these towns. Nothing creates more ill will than this sort of conduct. I do not sheet the blame home to the Aboriginal communities, for the vast majority of people there cannot read or write, have absolutely no understanding of normal accountancy procedures and have not the slightest idea about what processes they should go through for authorisations of purchases. They have no idea what their agents are doing but at the end of the day they suffer because taxpayers' money provided to them never reaches them. Added to that is the criticism and condemnation in these community towns about the benevolence cast upon the Aborigines.

Anyone who bothers to go to any of these towns will see the ill will and ill feeling. Much of it stems back to circumstances such as the ones I have set out. I wonder whether in 12 months' time I will produce three or four more auditor's reports and whether I will find that the number has gone from 12 to 16. In 12 months time will there be some proper mechanism and process? I say to Senator Tate that I can go to half a dozen more towns in the north-west of Western Australia and bring back the same evidence. I did not bother because I am giving an example-not exhaustive proof-but this problem is endemic right through these Aboriginal communities, at least in the north-west of Western Australia and I suspect in the greater part of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) rises to speak, I would just like to say something of a more general nature to underline the points that Senator Crichton-Browne has been raising very forcefully at a detailed level. I refer now to the operations of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the sheer lack of Public Service proficiency which this continual recitation of details underlines. I will come in a moment to a more specific aspect of the operations of that Department and in particular those of the departmental head, Mr Charles Perkins.

SPEECH.PARA: But the more general point I want to make is that these episodes which Senator Crichton-Browne, Senator Tambling and other honourable senators have mentioned in this chamber and also have been referring to during Estimates committee hearings continue to recur and, it would seem, continue to fail to be the subject of appropriate follow-up and the institution of appropriate controls. As Senator Crichton-Browne quite rightly said, in the end this kind of thing is the result of appalling administrative inefficiency and Public Service and ministerial failure-because in the end the Minister is responsible for the operation of the Department. If a Minister's department is not operating appropriately and his departmental head is no good he sacks him and gets another one who can produce a worthwhile and appropriately efficient and effective department to carry out the Government's policies, not just as some individual might deem they should be carried out, but according to proper procedures accountable to the electors and taxpayers of this country. That is where the Department of Aboriginal Affairs has been falling down. As Senator Crichton-Browne quite rightly said, every time it falls down the backlash is not upon such people as Mr Charles Perkins and some of his senior officers; it is upon the Aboriginal people.

I note in passing, as I said I would, that Mr Perkins had the impertinence the other day to make a public statement in which he branded me as the failed Treasury head, Senator Stone. I do not run around the country issuing defamation writs and stuff like that. I take the view that if one is in public life, one has to be prepared to be a bit robust and take it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bob Hawke does.

—I understand that the Prime Minister has had a penchant for that kind of activity but I am not wishing to follow the Prime Minister's deplorable example in that or in any other way. My point is simply that if one is in public life one has to be prepared to take it a bit, just as one should be able to hand it out a bit, if we are to have any robust debate in this country about matters of public moment. But I must say that the remarks by Mr Perkins about me do him no credit. I leave it to others to judge the accuracy or otherwise of Mr Perkins's personal description of me. I will take my chance in the history books of the country as to whether I have been a failure in my Public Service career compared to Mr Perkins. I am quite content to leave it to the archives to determine.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I want to make, and this is the only reason I raise this otherwise trivial incident is, that the matters we are talking about in this Committee this morning are matters arising out of the administration-I should actually say maladministration-of Mr Perkins's Department. Mr Perkins is personally responsible for that maladministration. It is about time this Government stopped operating a set of double standards in relation to its Public Service and adopted towards Mr Perkins the same disciplinary attitudes and principles of conduct and operation as it would if any other departmental secretary in its departmental structure were to carry on in this manner. So long as the Government refuses to grasp that nettle, along with a great many other nettles in this area which it is refusing to grasp, it will continue to flounder not only in terms of its policy performance but also in terms of the assessment of that policy performance by the people of this country.

I believe that the Department of Finance is in the process shortly of instituting a major change in its financial control procedures which will make departmental heads personally accountable for the manner in which they conduct the expenditure control over which they have authority or over which their departments or their Ministers have authority. I look forward to the day when an officer of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, including not least the Secretary to that Department, is held personally responsible for the kinds of defalcations, maladministrations, and in many cases one would have to say actual corruption, that are involved in the cases which have been brought before the chamber this morning by my colleagues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is unfair of Senator Stone to say of any departmental head that he or she should be responsible for every instance of misappropriation or corruption out in some of the organisations where funding is made available by transfers through that person's department. It would, of course, be culpable on the part of the department's officers and of the secretary to the department if no procedures were instituted to attempt first of all to prevent such occurrences, detecting them when they do occur, and dealing with them when they are revealed. Indeed any criticism would be very properly directed if those sorts of supervisory processes were not undertaken. I do not know whether Senator Crichton-Browne is going to raise more instances.
—How long have you got?

—Not very long. I want to go back and have some breakfast. I have been at meetings since 7.30 a.m., but I am prepared to stay a little longer. The fact is that it would have been more helpful if these matters had been raised at the Estimates Committee hearing. Maybe the honourable senator had a competing Estimates committee meeting and he could not attend. In so far as there are various auditors' reports which can be brought forward, I have no intention whatsoever of standing here and defending the sorts of practices which have been revealed by the auditors in their reports. On the other hand, I would not want to generalise entirely, and I think Senator Crichton-Browne did try at the end of his speech to put in a little balance. There are many instances where Aboriginal communities, having been entrusted with public moneys, have discharged that trust quite honourably and efficiently and, in the process, have gained self-esteem and self-determination in regard to their community affairs, which is regarded as very important.

SPEECH.PARA: So there are also many good instances of the operation of these communities with public moneys. The sorts of matters which Senator Crichton-Browne has brought to our attention would not be condoned by anybody, least of all I would think by those Aboriginal communities who are dependent on public goodwill for the flow of taxpayers' money and for living at harmony in the communities in which they find themselves. Those communities would be just as appalled as we are by some of the instances outlined. Steps are being taken, some of a more penal character, and sanctions are being applied, as well as other steps of the educative kind I outlined as part of the Government's program to make the awareness of certain management and bookkeeping practices part of the understanding of those who are put in charge of, and take responsibility for, these communities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly mindful of the fact that the Aboriginal Development Commission is a statutory authority and is quite independent of the Minister in its essential day to day decisions and judgments. The Elvira Koongie Park pastoral property was previously owned by the Western Australian Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and was subsequently sold to the ADC. It was then passed on in trust to a further group headed by Monty Gordon, a man who I might say is held in the highest regard in both the white and Aboriginal communities in Western Australia. He is on record as saying that the station was overvalued and that too much was paid for it and that it was in an appalling condition. As to the homestead and the outstations, I can tell Senator Tate now that I do not know anybody who would be happy to live there if something else were offered. Were any steps taken to ensure that the transaction was not only strictly commercial-I have no doubt it was-but that it was seen to be above board, inasmuch as it might be reasonable to say that there was a superficial conflict of interest?

—There are no officers of the ADC here, as there would have been at the Estimates Committee hearing. I recall seeing a Press response, I think from the vendor of those properties, which refuted some of the allegations that had been made. Did Senator Knowles ask a question on this?
—Yes.

—I undertook to give her an answer, and I will undertake to give one also to Senator Crichton-Browne, as to whether the Department had any role in this matter. When I get those answers both honourable senators may be satisfied, but if not, we can follow this matter up next week.

—I understand there is a time problem, certainly not for me but for others, so I will be brief and perhaps deal with this matter at another time. I ask whether the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies has been consulted properly, fully and frankly in respect of its absorption into the Commission, and whether or not the council of that quite outstanding group, which I think is acknowledged by everybody as having done some remarkable work, has agreed to its absorption into the Commission or would wish to stand alone and be able to continue its quite remarkable and excellent work independent of anybody else, maintaining the autonomy which has allowed it so far to conduct itself and its work in the way it has?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that consultations have been held with the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies. I am advised that the final form of its relationship with the new Commission has not been finally determined. As the Minister made clear in his statement of 27 April, he is continuing to consider a number of relatively minor adjustments to its operation. Final decisions have not been taken.
—Could you go back a couple of paragraphs?
—I am quoting from the Minister's statement. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies I am continuing to consider a number of relatively minor adjustments to their operation. Final decisions have not been taken.
That is all I have as far as the Minister's public statement on 27 April is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —But are they to go into the Commission?
—Final decisions have not been taken as to the future status and relationship of the Institute to the Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter that has caused me concern in relation to the sale of the Williamstown Dockyard. It seems to me that on the face of the documents the Government has bungled to the extent of losing over $20m of taxpayers' money. This clearly calls for explanation. I look forward to the explanation the Minister might give. I will expand briefly. When the Government determined to sell the Williamstown Dockyard it negotiated a price. It also agreed with the Australian Marine Engineering Corporation AMEC, the purchasers, that within the price there would be an allowance for redundancies. It was agreed that the anticipated redundancies would be 261 men and women and that the Commonwealth-they were Commonwealth public servants who would become redundant-would make the required redundancy payments and that they would amount to $4.8m. So the budgeting was done on that basis. Announcements were made to the public as to the sale price and the fact that over $4.5m would have to be paid for redundancies, which would reduce the sale price by that amount.

SPEECH.PARA: However, when we came to the Supplementary Estimates, we found that the position had vastly altered. Not only was the $4.8m provision for redundancy payments agreed prior to sale, as I indicated, but there was an additional figure for costs of sale, subsequent to the sale, of $26,758,000. Needless to say, we explored further how the Government could unexpectedly have had extra costs of over $26m. We found out that, of that figure, $21.775m was made up of extra redundancies. When the government negotiated, as I said, it understood that it would have to pay for 261 redundancies. It also agreed to pay for further employees whom the purchaser would make redundant or dismiss, or employees who would leave. Unexpected to this Government, that was a further 977 employees, as put to the Estimates Committee. This Government, therefore, has to find an extra $21.755m of taxpayers' money to pay out to these employees, thus effectively reducing the purchase price by over $21m. Or, if one wants to look at it in a different way, the private enterprise organisation that purchased the dockyard, in effect, purchased it for $21m less than had been agreed. Otherwise, in due course it would have had to take over the long term responsibility for these employees. Therefore, that was obviously written into the purchaser's price. So the Government has had to pay another $21.7m of taxpayers' money, whether because of failure in negotiations or failure in the contract remains unclear. Perhaps we will get some explanation from the Minister today.

One would have thought that in negotiating the contract it would be written into the contract that the total number of redundancies for which the Commonwealth had to pay without some recourse against the purchaser would be limited to the 261 employees. But it seems-we are told that the contract is confidential and we cannot see it-that it was not written into the contract, that there was a failure in this regard.

The Government, through its officers in the Estimates committee hearing, came back and said, `But under the contract, if any of these redundant persons are re-employed within a specified time frame, there will be a right of action for the Commonwealth against the company for the redundancy payments, although the redundancy payments are paid to the individuals. It does not take much imagination to realise that the company is highly unlikely to re-employ these people when it may have a liability to pay millions of dollars back to the Commonwealth. That is unlikely to occur. It is a disincentive to the re-employment of these people. It seems to me that at the very least the contract should have provided that, if in excess of 261 employees are made redundant within the specified time, the company would indemnify the Commonwealth for its extra obligation to the employees concerned.

In addition, the Government has determined to pay the private enterprise purchaser $3.595m for the employees who have remained with AMEC. That amount covers accrued long service and recreation leave entitlements. A further $1m was allocated for sick leave entitlements. The total is, therefore, as I said, an extra disbursement from the Government and the taxpayer of over $26m.

In the absence of explanation-which was not able to be given in satisfactory terms to the Estimates Committee-I would have thought that that was scandalous. It may well be scandalous that the work on the naval vessels being constructed in the dockyards has ceased for so long. But apart from that, a Defence Department which is pressing for adequate funds to properly maintain its responsibilities to the Government and the Australian people simply cannot afford to have $26m lost to it in this way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to some of the points that Senator Hill has made. The estimate of 261 redundancies and the $4.8m was based on the known redundancies at the time. It was always quite clear that there would be more redundancies than that. Until it actually took over the dockyard, the Australian Marine Engineering Corporation (AMEC) could not establish the degree of redundancies required. A clause in the contract gave AMEC the option to retrench further employees for a period of three months. I think it would have been very hard to sell the dockyard without such a clause in the contract. Until it took over, AMEC did not know what numbers it would retrench and what areas it would want retrenchments to occur in. I think Senator Hill has probably indicated the other leg of that-that if AMEC subsequently re-employs any of those people subject to retrenchment payments, AMEC itself must reimburse the Government for that particular amount. I would have thought that when the sale price was negotiated, the extent of possible retrenchments was involved in the estimate of what would be coming into the Government in terms of revenue from that sale.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, the figure of 261 was the known amount of retrenchments that would occur once the transfer was completed. Within the contract there was an option for AMEC, once it had assessed the situation, to make further retrenchments. That has occurred. It has occurred on a scale probably larger than one would have anticipated at the time. But certainly those retrenchments were not ruled out by any of the conditions of the contract.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) wishes to look at the information that was given to the Estimates Committee by officers of the Department of Defence, he will find that the picture is somewhat different from what he has just related to us. There is little doubt that the budgeting for the sale was done on the basis of 261 redundancies. The net sale price was put to the Australian people on the basis of those redundancies at a cost of $4.8m. The Government has taken the plaudits for the sale of the dockyard at a stated net profit, but we now find that there are additional unexpected costs of $26.7m, costs that I can assure you, Madam Temporary Chairman, a private sector vendor certainly would not have accepted without, as I indicated a few minutes ago, writing into the contract a right of indemnity. It just seems to me and, I think, to anyone who has perused the evidence in the estimates, that at the very least it is sloppy work on the part of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and on the part of the Department and it is costing the taxpayer an enormous sum of money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have much more to add. It seems eventually that Senator Hill's complaint is about the plaudits we got at the time of the sale. I cannot retrospectively remove those. It seems to me that the statements made at the time referring to 261 referred to the actual redundancies. I do not think there was any desire on the part of this Government to say that there would not be further redundancies. They were always a possibility once AMEC took over the Williamstown Dockyard. Those redundancies have occurred. I have indicated that I think they are at a much higher level than any of us would have liked. But they were always within the option of the contract. Probably having accepted that, Senator Hill went on to say that he did not think the negotiating skills used in drawing up that contract were therefore satisfactory. That is a matter for judgment and people will draw their own conclusions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of access for anyone to the new Parliament House is ultimately a matter for the Presiding Officers. Therefore, it is a matter that should have been raised in Estimates Committee A.
