SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to know that the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) is as horrified as I am. I know that, as the Minister responsible for the drivers' well-being, he will approach the President. The Minister having heard the same rumours as I did-that the Commonwealth car drivers have been told that they have been denied access on security grounds-I am surprised, I suppose, that he has not done something about it.

SPEECH.PARA: The mind boggles. If their security status is such that they are permitted to drive us to and fro, from our accommodation to Parliament House and back, and everywhere else, surely their security is good enough for them to be able to use the facilities in the new Parliament House. I am content that the Minister will take this matter up with the Presiding Officers and will not allow such denial of access to occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might just add that I do not track down every rumour I hear. There are not that many hours in the day.
—As a demonstration of good public relations, I would have thought that that rumour would have been nipped in the bud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Initially I want to ask a couple of questions in relation to the sale of the Australian Embassy precincts and property in Tokyo. Since asking a question on this matter in Estimates Committee E on 21 April, I have received some supplementary advice from the Department of Administrative Services. I asked whether we had a guarantee that a capital gains tax would not be paid on the proceeds of the sale. I have now had a response from the Department, which took my question partly on notice, which states;

SPEECH.PARA: The Japanese Government has not yet responded formally concerning the matter of taxation in respect of the surplus land recently sold in Tokyo. An interim response has been received which implies a favourable decision would be forthcoming.

At the Estimates Committee E hearing on 21 April an officer of the Department said that a contract for the sale had been expected to be signed the following day-the twenty-second. Did that contract signing go through and was the contract subject to no capital gains tax being paid?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that the Department is fairly certain that the contract was signed the following day. It would surprise me if one could write into a contract acceptance or avoidance of the tax. I do not see that that would be proper. My advice is that the Japanese Government has not yet responded formally concerning the matter of taxation in respect of the surplus land sold in Tokyo. I hope I am not reading exactly the same response as Senator Short has received.
—I think you are.

—In that case I will desist. The honourable senator knows that the advice of the Australian Taxation Office is that the tax will not be levied, due to the application of sovereign immunity. Japanese legal advice was obtained to the effect that the gain realised by Australia on the disposition of any portion of the present embassy site will be exempt from taxation. I cannot add much more to that other than that I would be very surprised if there was a reference to capital gains tax in the contract. We are not aware of such a reference.

—I am surprised that, given the amount at stake, we would have signed that contract without a cast iron guarantee that the sale proceeds would not be subject to capital gains tax. We are talking, as I understand it, about a difference of hundreds of millions of dollars. That is why I asked whether any guarantee had somehow or other been given in our dealings with the Japanese to ensure that the proceeds would be free of capital gains tax.

—As part of these dealings advice was given and discussions were held. We acted on the best possible advice in handling this matter. I am not sure that any government would give an absolute guarantee in advance. The indications are that the proceeds of the sale will not be subject to capital gains tax and we acted on that basis. There have been a lot of stories about the sale of this site-Senator Short would have read many of them-such as that Australia was going to get $320m and that $380m had been awarded to X company, when X company in fact missed out. In the end, even if the proceeds were subject to capital gains tax-I do not think they will be-we will probably get more for the site than was ever speculated.
—If the contracts have been signed, what was the price in terms of both the yen and the Australian dollar?

—My recollection is it was 57 billion yen or, subject to the exchange rate, roughly $640m. It may have been lower than that because that figure was based on an exchange rate of 90 yen to the dollar. I think it was about 95 yen to the dollar on 20 May when the sale occurred. However, the price was in the ballpark of $640m. Allowing for the exchange rate, it was probably a little less than that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was any provision made to protect the Australian dollar proceeds against a movement in the exchange rate that has occurred with the yen? I was prompted to say that by, amongst other things, Mr West's Press release of 11 March, which stated that it was expected that the deal would bring in approximately $640m at an exchange rate of 90 yen to the dollar, as Senator Ray has said. It stated further:

SPEECH.PARA: However, the final amount Australia will receive will depend upon the exchange rate at the time the contracts are finalised in a few weeks' time.
I repeat: Was anything done in the form of cover to protect the Australian dollar proceeds? Did we cover that matter at all?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it is normal practice to do that, but I will make some inquiries and let Senator Short know whether that was the case. Governments anticipating exchange rates, as he knows, is a very grey area. I would have thought that it was assumed that the exchange rate fluctuations would not be great, as has turned out to be the case. We have had a less volatile exchange rate this year. I will seek some further information on whether any thought was given, if you like, to insurance or an each-way bet and give it to Senator Short.

—Am I correct in saying that if the exchange rate applicable at the time was 95 yen to the dollar-that sounds a little high-compared to the 90 yen to the dollar mentioned in the Press release of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) of 11 March, we are talking about a loss to the Commonwealth, in rough figures, of $30m? That is a lot of money.
—As I said, I do not have that sort of detail immediately to hand, but I have promised to get it to Senator Short and I will do that as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now turn to another topic. I left on notice with the Department the following question:

SPEECH.PARA: Which members and senators have since the last election established or will in the near future be establishing new electorate offices, as distinct from moving into pre-existing Electorate Offices?

I thank the Department for its detailed responses. I wish to ask some questions about the answers that we have received. The figures are divided into two categories-fit-out and furniture-and there is a budgeted figure for each and a spent figure for each. What is the basis for the amount to be spent on fit-out and furniture for these offices in view of the wide variations in the figures?

TALK.START.PARA: —Initially, the estimates are based on an inspection of the offices and the amount of work that is regarded as necessary to bring them up to scratch. Just how expensive or how cheap a particular office is also varies from city to city and State to State according to the prevailing market forces.

—I would like to look at some of the figures in a little more detail. The first list is given for New South Wales. Senator Michael Baume's office change involved a budgeted fit-out of $5,000 and it apparently came in at $4,300.
—I watched for waste there.

—I am delighted at what the honourable senator has done very assiduously on behalf of the Australian taxpayer over recent years, at a great saving. The outfitting of Mr Michael Lee's office was budgeted at $35,000 and in fact came in at $49,000. There was a nil budget figure for furniture for Mr Lee but, in the event, $3,546 was spent on furniture.
—About 12 times more than on my office.
—Yes. What is the explanation for a difference such as that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The explanation is very simple. The figures depend on the task needed to bring an office in a particular area up to scratch. The position is that members of Parliament, both Labor and Liberal-there is generally no distinction-are becoming very mobile, generally upwardly, in their wants in terms of their offices. The major moves tend to occur after an election. After the 1987 election the new senators and members wanted offices. I might say that some of their proposals were quite extraordinary and have been knocked back. But existing members tend to leave a move until after an election and they move fairly rapidly in many cases. In some cases the expenditure is totally justifiable. Some of the existing offices were fire traps and the working conditions were becoming intolerable.

SPEECH.PARA: Given the new and munificent largesse we have extended in providing facsimile machines, computers and a third staff member, many members have found their offices are too small to accommodate that Government largesse and have subsequently moved. But it really does depend on the task. There are certain standard provisions in terms of air-conditioning and partitioning for members. In some cases they are more expensive than others. I am very pleased to say that Senator Michael Baume's figures are not high. Maybe we will scale everything down to suit Senator Baume's requirements. I would have to be very careful that there was not excessive expenditure according to that ruthless waste watcher, Senator Baume. I will not get into the game of comparing individual offices. I will not get into the game of saying what rent, fitout, furniture and conditions some members, Liberal and Labor, have written asking me for. That would not profit anyone in either this chamber or the other.

TALK.START.PARA: —The average figure is in the order of $30,000 to $35,000. Can the Minister explain why the budgeted figure for the fitout of Senator Schacht's new office was $130,000 and the amount actually spent was $118,761?

—I would have to seek a breakdown of that before I could say why his figure was particularly high. It also depends on the area in which one seeks to have an office. As I say, fitout costs do vary enormously. It just depends on the degree of change needed in the offices. Obviously I do not know the breakdown of every individual office and why a cost may be high. I will seek that information.
—How on earth could a budget of $130,000 be approved in the first instance for any senator or member?

—It really depends on where the office is located. These days providing security, air-conditioning, partitioning, et cetera tends to be a very expensive process. That would be one of the highest costs of fit-out. Generally it depends on which office one moves into and how much work is needed in it. I think the honourable senator is right when he says the general average for fit-out is $35,000 to $40,000. There is no doubt that the cost of fit-out has grown much faster than the consumer price index in recent years.
—Is the Minister saying that there is no figure of which the Department would simply say, `That is too high'?
—No, there isn't.
—There is no figure? Would the Minister not rule out $130,000 for the fit-out of an office?

—It depends on the difficulty of finding an office in the location that the member or senator requires. Of course we would rule out an extravagant figure or extravagant needs. If a member wanted personalised bookshelves or something along those lines, or wanted us to move those sorts of things for him, we would draw the line. A whole range of those requests are made. Everyone basically gets a standard office. The size limit is 90 square metres, but that limit has been approached with compassion by Ministers over the years so that members are not squeezed too far. From memory Senator Schacht's office is in excess of 90 square metres, as there is a tendency for most offices these days to be. As I said, I do not have the particular details of Senator Schacht's office available to me at the moment, but I will have a look at them. Fit-out cost is not automatically approved.

—I would like to deal with a couple of other offices, whilst bearing the Minister's general comments in mind. Mrs Harvey's new office has $65,000 budgeted for it. That also sounds like an extraordinarily high figure, although it fails dismally in comparison with the budget for the office of Senator Schacht. Does the Minister have any explanation for that high figure?
—I do not have the details available, so I do not have an explanation.

—Will the Minister take that question on notice, and if he does not have the answer to my following questions will he also take them on notice? The figure budgeted for Senator Devereux's office in Hobart was $62,800, while $65,816 was actually spent. The figure budgeted for Mr Duncan Kerr's office was $50,000, and about the same amount was spent. Compare these figures with the figure for Senator Calvert's office, also located in the Hobart area. An amount of $35,000 was budgeted for him and only $28,300 was spent. The variations are very wide. Almost without exception the variations at the higher levels relate to the offices of Labor senators and members. One could be forgiven for being a little cynical if one suggested that different standards appear to apply in terms of the figures approved for offices.

—Senator Short has now got to the guts of his question. I categorically say I apply no different standard to any member of this Parliament in terms of accommodation, fitout or other entitlements. I say that categorically. I could, if I thought that was going to be the view put around, very easily square the account. I will not. I could very easily go to some of the letters from Liberals that come across my desk requesting massive rents and furnishings. I will not. I know that was not quite Senator Short's implication but it will be taken that way. I just say that applications for office conditions, et cetera, are applied very fairly. That is not done just as a matter of principle, I might add; it is done out of plain self-interest because the moment one applies different standards one gets caught out and exposed.

—I have two more questions to raise, the first of which relates to the figure of $172,000 for the electorate office of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). Further information supplied in a response to a question by Senator Michael Baume points out that the figure was for a combined ministerial and electorate office. I certainly take that point. The answer said that it was necessary because there was no suitable alternative accommodation available. Mr Beazley has been the Minister for Defence, or Minister assisting, for approximately 5 1/2 years now, so I presume the security arrangements for him, which would be very substantial, would always have applied. Can the Minister give me any further information on why that move was necessary, given what would appear to be the understandably heavy security costs involved?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my practice to question why either Ministers or members move from their electorate or ministerial offices. Mr Beazley, obviously wanted a combined ministerial and electorate office. This is not unusual for Ministers whose electorates are a little volatile, given the fact that Ministers are away from their electorates so often and that prevents them from doing their constituent duties. Ministers are never given any privileges by their electoral opponents, nor should they be, because they cannot be a local member. I indicate to Senator Short that approval is not automatic. At least one Minister elected in 1987 has not been given premises. The Minister's application for office accommodation has been rejected on the grounds of cost. I can think of five such applications since the last election from members and senators-some old, some new-whose applications for office accommodation have been rejected on the grounds of costs or size of office. There is an approach that if the cost is too high or the size is too big they can be knocked back. It is very irritating to the member of parliament. As I said, one member has been a Minister for 10 months and we have not even started work on his ministerial electorate office yet because he represents an electorate where rent is exorbitant and fit-out costs are enormous, as Senator Short pointed out, and where getting the right configuration, down to 180 square metres-or, let us be generous, say, 200 square metres-has not been possible.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not question Ministers as to why they want to locate their offices in particular areas. If it comes to the point of absolute extravagance or expense we question it and say that the office will have to be moved somewhere else, but we cannot question the actual move. We can question where the member moves to but not the actual move. That is up to the member of parliament. If there are other factors such as an enormous amount of dead rent, we will take that into account and say, `You will find it very hard to move unless we can be guaranteed a tenant to pick up the dead rent cost too'. All these things have to be taken into account but if Senator Short writes to me and says that he wants to move his electorate office from, I believe, the Brunswick area and set up elsewhere for good reasons-his power base in the Liberal Party may have shifted to the eastern suburbs although I am sure it will not-I would not question him. I would not say, `You are only moving out of expediency'. If he wanted to move he could move.

TALK.START.PARA: —When a member of parliament moves from one office to another is it normal for the furniture to be moved as well? The reason I ask-one can pick various examples-is that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) has moved her electoral office in the Australian Capital Territory with not only a fit-out cost of $60,000 but also a furniture cost of $20,000. Would it not be normal for members who move office to take their furniture with them? If so, how are those figures for furniture justified?

—It is normal for members to take their furniture with them. Mrs Kelly may have been on the waiting list for furniture replacement. As Senator Short knows, we replace furniture consistently and I hope that it is done in order of fairness rather than taking the squeaky wheel approach. I sometimes felt I was subject to that some years ago as I always seemed to be last on the list for furniture replacement. I will find out whether the move to the new electorate office involved purchasing new furniture just for the sake of it or whether Mrs Kelly was on the list, it was about the time that her furniture was to be replaced, and the opportunity was taken to do it at the time of the move.

—I also want to refer to the answers to Senator Short's question on notice regarding the fit-outs for new offices. My estimation is that the average new office fit-out expenditure for 10 coalition members, not including the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), was $29,146.30. I have also estimated that the average new office fit-out expenditure for 15 Government members, not including the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), was $54,711. This average amount is nearly double that of the coalition. Is there an explanation for this?

—I have already given the negative explanation for that. It may well be that Labor members of parliament, working much harder than others, need better conditions-but I doubt that very much. I do not have a direct explanation for that. It has been suggested that Opposition members may be more frugal. I will not enter into that debate without at least taking my gloves off. I do not have a particular explanation for it other than to say that, as far as I am concerned, there is no element of bias in terms of the judgment. I might point out that there are two different sections of the Department of Administrative Services that deal with these matters. Parliamentary and ministerial services come into it fairly late in the piece. I am not involved in day to day supervision in that area. Senator Newman knows of the rent and fit-out costs. The property division does the initial negotiation, estimates and so on, although in most cases I see the final figures.

—I thank the Minister for that answer. I recognise that I was talking about expenditure. I advise the Minister that I have also calculated that the average figure budgeted by the Department for the Opposition members was $26,500 and the average figure budgeted for the 15 Government members was $53,653. So in the approval at the initial stage double the amount was budgeted for a Government member as for an Opposition member. The Minister says that he does not want to get into particularities and individuals but I have to say that a consistent imbalance of that nature needs an explanation and I would like one.

—It may well be that different members from different political representations have different needs; it may be as simple as that. If Senator Newman is suggesting that the overall fit-out costs are too high per se and that we should reduce and further standardise electoral offices, we could look at it, but I do not want to at this stage. I want to give as much flexibility as possible to members of parliament to have offices to suit their needs. I do not want rigid rules such as those which existed under Labor and in the early Fraser years when members could only have 600 square feet; that is, about 60 square metres. They could not have an inch more than that; they could not have a different configuration. Especially in an electorate of different socioeconomic standards, one could have an office only in the down end of the market-even though all the transport goes to the central area. I do not want to impose those sorts of conditions on members of parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Am I to assume from the Minister's answer that it is not a result of Government policy? I hope that it is not also an example of the politicisation of the Public Service. I find the imbalance between the two averages so dramatic that they need investigation.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to pass on to another matter which Senator Short has already raised; that is, the fit-out for the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) of $172,000. I recognise that the additional answers show that this is a combined electoral and ministerial office, that no suitable alternative accommodation was available and that air-conditioning and substantial security measures had to be provided. Why were the Minister's previous arrangements unsatisfactory? He was a Minister prior to this new fit-out. I know Senator Ray has adverted to it, but why were there no suitable alternatives? Is it not a fact that in Western Australia there has been an oversupply of office accommodation in the last couple of years? Finally, what was the expenditure on the air-conditioning and security arrangements?

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me first of all say that I reject out of hand Senator Newman's reference to the politicisation of the Department causing that differential. Secondly, I will not have an inquisition as to why Minister Beazley wants to move his office. I indicated before that I take Ministers, Opposition office holders and other members at their word if they say they want to move their office. That is what I did and that is what I will continue to do. I will not change that policy. Senator Newman asked specific questions about air-conditioning without seriously expecting me to give an answer right now. She spoke about an oversupply of offices in Western Australia. I do not think many Western Australian parliamentarians have found that to be the case.
—Oh, yes.

—Some Western Australian members of parliament who have sought suitable office space have found it very difficult. I do not want to cite chapter and verse who, but I can think of three examples from three parties of members who found great difficulty in locating a suitable office in the Perth area, especially in the Perth business district. I do not know how one matches that demand with the supply question: Senator Newman says that there is an oversupplied market but not everyone has found it easy to find accommodation.

—I also draw the Minister's attention to the fact that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) has had her office fitted out at a cost of $69,150. That means that the two Defence Ministers have just spent $241,150 on their offices. As Service married quarters are being renovated at a maximum cost of $30,000 to $35,000 each that means that the two Ministers between them have used the equivalent of the amount needed to renovate homes for seven or eight defence families. Is this an example of the Government's priorities?
—That was a political point.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask: In light of Minister Evans's statement today that the privatisation debate is dead because the Australian Council of Trade Unions has vetoed it, will the Minister deny the rumours circulating amongst independent schools that the anti-private schools lobby, including the teachers unions, has been successful in having tax deductability for donations to private school building funds abolished or tampered with in the May economic statement to be brought down next week?

—I suppose that honourable senators can ask any questions they like here. But it is not my function in answering questions to confirm or deny rumours which are circulating, perhaps in the community outside. Secondly, I inform Senator Bishop that it is not my function to say what will be done in the May economic statement. As I have said in the Senate before, if Senator Bishop can possess her soul in patience until 25 May she will know exactly what has happened in the May statement. I am not going to speculate about any things that may be or may not be in that statement.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer him to data apparently held by the Bureau of Meteorology in Melbourne which could be used to forecast rainfall more accurately in marginal cereal growing districts in Australia. I ask: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the article in the Adelaide Advertiser on the El Nino ocean current and its links with dry-land farming in Australia? Is it correct, as claimed, that funds available to the Bureau of Meteorology are insufficient to monitor this vital ocean current adequately? Could there be a good return in the form of more accurate farming decisions through the provision of extra funds to the Bureau of Meteorology?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to do a Barry Jones impersonation here, but I cannot. I have seen the article. I am aware of the dependence on cereal production in southern Australia and climate fluctuations associated with the El Nino. I recognise the benefits that would flow from improved monitoring of this phenomenon. In order to provide useful advice to the rural community on the current state of El Nino in the Pacific Ocean and on the likely seasonal developments over Australia, the National Climate Centre of the Bureau of Meteorology requires daily data from around the globe for an adequate understanding of the atmospheric and oceanic processes involved. Expert staff interpret this data. A major international monitoring and research effort has been under way for some years as part of the climate research program. The Bureau, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and Australian scientists have played a significant part in the development of the program and are participating in the effort to the maximum extent possible with their available resources.

ANSWER.PARA: The data obtained through these international efforts, especially from the US and Japanese meteorological satellites, have greatly improved the Bureau's understanding of the El Nino phenomenon and its associated climatic impacts in Australia. The National Climate Centre is working closely with the US Climate Analysis Centre and, for the past year, has been issuing regular monthly bulletins to the scientific community on the state of the climate system over the Southern Hemisphere. The Bureau's ability to monitor these climatic fluctuations and its scientific understanding of phenomena such as El Nino and the so-called southern oscillation have reached the stage where it expects soon to be able to begin issuing regular public advice through the media on the general state of the climate system over Australia and the likely seasonal outlooks. I understand that the basic Public Service will be able to provide the resources presently available to the Bureau. I will give more details of this later. I would like it understood that this was not a dorothy dixer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Now that the Government has buckled to back bench and Australian Council of Trade Unions pressure and abandoned its plans to change party policy at the June Australian Labor Party Federal Conference to allow changes to ownership of major public enterprises I ask: How does the Government propose to find the massive amounts of capital required by some of these enterprises, in particular the $600m that Qantas Airways Ltd needs and the $250m required by Australian Airlines over the next two years and three years respectively?
—One way is to have a larger deficit, as you used to.

—I note Senator Walsh's interjection that one way of doing so is to have a larger deficit. That may well be the Minister's reply but I suspect that Senator Evans will be able to deal with this question without Senator Walsh's help. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously I do not accept the premise of Senator Chaney's question and his tendentious language about `buckling'. On the referendum issue Mr Howard buckled when his Party room overruled a decision of his own shadow Cabinet. ANSWER.PARA: If we are looking for buckling we do not have to look very much further than the other side of this chamber and the leadership of the parties that confront us here. TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Resources about a quarantine matter. Is the Minister aware of the recent newspaper reports about Japanese woodchip ships cleaning their ballast tanks on arrival in Tasmania and by doing so dumping tonnes of dangerously contaminated sediment into the ports of both Hobart and Triabunna? Can the Minister say whether any testing of this ballast water has taken place and, if so, with what results? Is there any truth in the claim that the dumping of ballast water has had and will have a deleterious effect on Tasmania's growing marine culture industry? Did a scientist from the University of Tasmania, Dr Hallegraeff, approach the Federal Government about this problem and the harm it was doing to the ecology and marine industries of the ports? What can and will the Commonwealth Government do about this problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of recent Press reports that Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) scientists have found live spores in ballast water dumped by foreign vessels in Hobart and Triabunna, which are thought to be capable of seeding toxic plankton blooms. I am advised that the CSIRO scientists in Hobart, including Dr Hallegraeff, to whom Senator Coates referred, have been testing ballast water and sediments from Japanese woodchip container ships visiting Triabunna and are investigating further the incidence of spores in ballast sediments from foreign ships entering Tasmanian marine culture areas. Quarantine officers have been involved in the drawing of samples for this purpose. It is difficult to assess the extent, if any, of past damage caused by such dumping. The CSIRO studies have highlighted the potential dangers involved and further work should provide a clearer picture when it is completed.

ANSWER.PARA: The problem of accidental importation of marine life through ballast water has been known for many years. As well as the CSIRO work, of which my Department has been aware, there are a number of cases of introductions overseas and in Australia through ballast water. Studies by officers of the Fisheries Research Institute, the New South Wales Department of Agriculture and the Australian Museum have highlighted similar potential dangers. Despite investigations into means of controlling or eliminating species in ballast tanks, no practical method has yet been developed. The only known practical method of control at this time is exchange of ballast water while the vessel is at sea. However, that is not always a practical alternative because of the inherent dangers, especially in heavy seas. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service is monitoring the developments in Tasmania and hopes that soon it can develop a practical response to that problem.

I might say to Senator Coates, since he has raised this question with me, that I will be scrutinising the activities of the Department to make sure that as soon as possible we can give him an answer on what remedial action can be taken in this particular case.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Aged Care. In view of the fact that many Australians are complaining about inability to obtain first home ownership grants, can the Minister confirm or deny that these grants are being handed out freely to newly arrived New Zealand citizens? Can the Minister supply the Senate with the latest figures on first home ownership grants awarded to New Zealand citizens who have recently arrived in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can say to the first part of Senator Sheil's question that first home owners assistance is not handed out freely to newly arrived New Zealand citizens or newly arrived citizens of any nationality. No assistance or advance of assistance maybe paid to anyone until the applicant or one of the joint applicants has become an Australian citizen or obtained permanent resident status in Australia. Eligibility for assistance under the first home owners scheme cannot be assessed until the applicant, or in the case of a joint applicant, one of them has lived in Australia for a full financial year as an Australian citizen or with permanent residential status.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason for that is to ensure that the scheme's income test is applied to a full year of income so that those more recently arrived are not placed at an advantage compared with longer term residents. To prevent hardship in cases where it is clear that the applicant's income will not exceed the limits, an estimate of income may be made and an advance paid of likely entitlement. Estimates of income are reconciled subsequently against the relevant tax assessment notice. If actual income is then found through some change in circumstances to have exceeded the estimate and an overpayment has resulted, the amount of overpayment is then recovered. Otherwise, there is no distinction in the application of the scheme's requirements as between applicants, whatever their country of origin.

No statistics are kept, however, relating to the country of origin of applicants because once people have achieved permanent resident status or are Australian citizens, they are treated properly and equally and it is not then necessary to disclose their country of origin. Therefore, as I have explained, the Government aims to treat uniformly all applicants for assistance under the first home owners scheme. I should add that since the scheme's inception over 286,000 households have been approved for assistance amounting to over $1.05 billion. Many migrants to Australia have been assisted within these figures to establish themselves as part of the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Home Affairs a question arising out of the vacancy created by the disqualification of former Senator Robert Wood. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the status of the electorate office previously occupied by Mr Wood?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In dealing with, if you like, the aftermath of the High Court decision, we have regarded former Senator Wood as having the same status as someone who had retired or shuffled off this mortal coil. Basically, that means that we allowed him to give his staff two weeks notice and to keep his electorate office open for two weeks. As a bonus I threw in a single fare back to Sydney for him on the particular day on which it occurred. I am now being subjected to a very spontaneous campaign from elements within New South Wales who suggest to me that his electorate office should remain open until the matter is resolved. I do not think that that is an appropriate course of action. I am not going to accede to those requests and I suggest that the people who are writing me letters open an office themselves; with the savings on the postage, the telephones, the telexes and the facsimiles they can probably afford it.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not think we could set such a precedent because there is going to be a recount. I cannot anticipate what that recount will bring up. There is still a 1:100 chance that it may not be the Nuclear Disarmament Party that gets elected. I intend to pursue that course. As and when we get a new senator from New South Wales resulting from the High Court decision, the moment that person is established the conditions of staff and office will be re-established.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence: Is it true that two Royal Australian Navy ships, the Stalwart, which is the acting fleet flagship, and the Jervis Bay, a training ship, have been diverted from a planned four-day visit to Cairns to be on stand-by off Vanuatu? If it is true, can the Government inform the Senate as to the scope of military activity that is intended for these ships?
—I do not have any knowledge of such a decision. I will get further details and get back to Senator Macklin, hopefully before the end of Question Time.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SALE OF BELL GROUP LTD SECURITIES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I refer to the proposed private hearing by the National Companies and Securities Commission on the recent sale of the Bell Group Ltd securities. I ask: Has the Government been informed of the nature of this hearing or inquiry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that many honourable senators will be interested in the fact that the National Companies and Securities Commission has announced a private hearing into the acquisition and disposal of securities in Bell Group Ltd. The hearings, which will be held in private, commence on Monday, 23 May, and are expected to extend over one or two weeks. Until the hearing is completed the Commission has asked the boards of Bell Group Ltd and Bell Resources Ltd not to make any further appointments to the boards of those companies. The Commission expects to take evidence from Mr Alan Bond, Mr Holmes a Court, representatives of the State Government Insurance Commission, other professional advisers and others. It is also likely that the directors of the Bell Resources group of companies will be called. The Commission has been advised that the State Government Insurance Commission will cooperate.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commission has not alleged any contra- vention of companies or securities laws but is holding the hearing under section 36 of the National Companies and Securities Commission Act to consider whether it should exercise any of its powers or functions under the legislation in respect of the transactions. TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts and Territories to the longstanding practice of adjusting payroll tax exemption levels in the Australian Capital Territory to keep them in line with the exemption level which operates in New South Wales. I ask: Is the Minister aware that no adjustment has been made to Australian Capital Territory exemption levels since July 1986, with the result that the threshold in the Australian Capital Territory is $200,000 whereas in New South Wales it is now $400,000? Does the Minister recall the statement of the Minister for the Arts and Territories, Mr Punch, on 16 February this year that he had asked his officers to look urgently at the need to adopt similar provisions to those applying in New South Wales in terms of threshold levels and rates of payroll tax in the Australian Capital Territory? Can the Minister say when the Government will act to remove this disincentive to business in the Australian Capital Territory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the statement that Minister Punch made some time back. I am aware that officers of the Department have been working on the problem. I am not aware of when an announcement will be made, but I shall endeavour to find that out for Senator Reid. If I can tell her by the end of Question Time, then I shall.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs say where migrants to Australia are coming from and what effect this will have on the birthplace mix of the population in the long term?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator for raising the matter, which is of concern to many. It is a matter that has attracted a great deal of misunderstanding. I welcome the opportunity to set the record straight. We are now taking migrants from more countries. In 1986-87 the largest source of migrants was the United Kingdom and Ireland, which accounted for 20 per cent of all permanent arrivals. The second largest source was New Zealand, which accounted for 12 per cent of the intake. A distant third was Vietnam, with 6 per cent, followed by the Philippines, with just under 6 per cent and South Africa, with 4 per cent. There are no less than 19 countries which each contribute more than one per cent of the intake.

ANSWER.PARA: Some have been saying that as a result of changing immigration trends those who are Australian born will soon find themselves in the minority. Of course, this is nonsense and will not happen. Because the absolute size of any particular birthplace intake is small compared to the total population, the overall birthplace mix of the population is projected to change little. Even with an intake of 150,000 annually-higher than the current program-the Australian born component is projected to be 75.3 per cent in the year 2025 compared with 78.7 per cent presently. A continuation of present immigration trends would see European born, including those from the United Kingdom and Ireland, remaining the next largest group, making up 11 per cent of the population, followed by the Asian born group, making up just 7 per cent. We must try to bring a sense of perspective to this question. Diversity in the intake brings clear benefits to Australian society.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the Minister agree with Senator Walsh's recent statement that too often public enterprises operate in their own organisational interests and that of their management and employees rather than the public interest and that public enterprise is often a net drain on the Budget? Does the Minister support the desperate rearguard action being waged by the Australian Labor Party Federal Secretary, Bob Hogg, and more recently Senator Gareth Evans, to keep the privatisation issue alive beyond the National Conference or does he accept Mr Crean's ex cathedra fiat that privatisation is dead? I refer to the Minister's well-known disinclination to adopt the recommendations of Australia Reconstructed, the Australian Council of Trade Unions' blueprint for the Australian economy. Does the Minister's lack of enthusiasm stem from an objection to the basic concept of that report or merely to the funding mechanisms proposed? Will the Minister give an assurance that the Federal Government will not support any compromise arrangements with the trade union movement on the privatisation issue which would result in part of the proceeds from the sale of public assets or government business enterprises being used to fund any schemes along the lines of a national development fund or a national employment and training fund?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope my colleagues in the Senate will pardon me; it is a long question and I should take about an hour and a quarter to answer it if I was to answer it properly. I will try to deal with some of the points. Firstly, the honourable senator asked me whether I agree with Senator Walsh, particularly in relation to an alleged comment that he made that public enterprises often operate in their own interests rather than the public interest.
—Not alleged.

—Thank you, Senator. My thespian friend has given me a bit of coaching again. I am sure that is correct, Senator Alston, just as it is true of major private enterprises. They operate in their own interests rather than in the public interest. I do not find anything particularly exceptional about that except for the context in which the statement was made. I agree with Senator Walsh.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, the honourable senator referred to a desperate rearguard action about the privatisation debate. The so-called privatisation debate involves big issues of public policy for this country. As I read what the Liberal Party of Australia has to say on this issue it has adopted a set of ideological blinkers about it all-four legs good, two legs bad sort of stuff, in the Orwellian sense. I do not think the Opposition has made a very intelligent contribution to the debate. There are big issues of public policy which the Labor Government and the Labor Party will continue to discuss. I do not regard it as damaging or detrimental to do that.

With regard to the comment that privatisation is dead, I think we ought to get our terms right and understand what we mean by privatisation. Different things are meant in different contexts about privatisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that what is wrong with Gareth? He does not understand.

—I am not saying that. I am saying that the debate about the future of public enterprises in Australia has been characterised as the privatisation debate. Senator Evans's concerns-which he referred to in answer to a question from, I think, Senator Chaney today-all along have related to the questions of efficiency and accountability of public enterprises and the capital requirements of public enterprises.
—Why gag debate?

—I do not need any help from Senator Walters. Those questions all relate to the earlier part of the honourable senator's question about the interests in which public enterprises operate. They are legitimate questions for discussion. The word `privatisation' is sometimes said to embrace all those considerations, but in my view it does not. Simplistically, privatisation means selling public enterprises to the private sector. Senator Evans has a different set of concerns which he is addressing and about which honourable senators will hear in due course.

ANSWER.PARA: Another part of the question alleged my disinclination to embrace the Australia Reconstructed document. I have some admiration for elements of the document and some criticisms of it. The criticisms relate largely to the fact that it is based on the Swedish model, which is a very different model from one which we might profitably use in this country-for a variety of reasons. I do not want to go into all those reasons now. The last part of the question concerned whether this Government would rule out the possibility of a national development fund and a national employment and training fund. The answer to the first part of that question is that I do not know, but I believe so. The answer to the second part of that question is no, we would not rule out the possibility of some form of national training fund. It is seen by this Government as a crucial issue-that is, the re-skilling of the work force, the continuing upgrading of work force skills, and things like that. There is a very important debate about who pays for that. Does the taxpayer pay for it or do the beneficiaries of it pay? That is a legitimate question for debate. I am certainly not going to rule out--

TALK.START.PARA: —Or the employers.

—Yes, or the employers, as they do in many other countries. As Senator Chaney knows-and Senator Alston probably does not know-one of the elements of that debate in Australia has been that those companies which do train and re-train workers on a consistent basis have the legitimate gripe that when they have done that other companies which do not bother to do any training or re-training take those workers by offering them additional incentives of one kind or another.
—Why have you gagged the debate?

—I indicated earlier to Senator Walters that I am not particularly helped by her interjections. That was so when I began to answer this question and it is still so now. Finally, the Government regards the training issue as very important. We will not rule out the possibility of something of that kind being done, because of the importance which we attach to it. The Australia Reconstructed document is like a curate's egg; it has good and bad parts. Many things have to be looked at and examined closely by Government in a constructive approach to that document.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer for Prices. I refer him to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of Wednesday, 18 May 1918-I should have said `1988'-by Ross Gittins.
—He could have written it 70 years ago.

—He could have written it 70 years ago, as the honourable senator says. A rather dramatic cartoon by Rollo Fazzari appeared with the article, which made the point almost as well as Ross Gittins did. The article and the cartoon dealt with the price of motor vehicle spare parts. The article was critical of the prices charged and said that they were unconscionable. I ask the Minister whether he agrees that prices for spare parts are unconscionable. Does he wish to make any comments on the article as it referred to the imposition on the public of the cost of spare parts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not read one of the articles to which Senator Cooney referred or, if I have, I cannot remember doing so. I have seen the article in the Sydney Morning Herald to which Senator Cooney referred, and I can say that the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA) recently conducted an inquiry into the prices of replacement parts for passenger motor vehicles. That inquiry was brought about because of concern, as expressed in the Gittins article but also expressed to the previous Minister for prices and consumer affairs, by consumers and the industry, particularly the insurance industry-an industry which has had to meet the impact of spare part prices on insurance premiums. The report found in general that prices had increased in some respects because of the depreciation of the Australian dollar. However, the report also showed that this development had led to some importers re-examining their sources of supply. As I shall outline later, there has been a beneficial effect from that.

ANSWER.PARA: We are talking about a particularly complex industry. About 5,000 models of cars are on Australian roads, as has been indicated by Repco. A total of 100,000 different spare parts are on the market throughout Australia. Companies keep stocks of those parts for up to 10 years. So one has to keep margins in mind when one considers the industry as a whole. The report identified a number of barriers to competition, and the PSA was very firmly of the view that a more competitive environment would have a beneficial effect on prices and the quality of goods which ultimately go to consumers.

The report identified a number of barriers. One barrier on which the PSA will concentrate in the near future will be that aspect of the market that deals with genuine parts. There is a strong feeling in the community, as stressed by the manufacturers of these parts, that consumers have to accept genuine parts when replacing parts in their motor vehicles. That is partly because of the intricate network of franchise dealerships that is endemic in this industry. As the PSA pointed out, in many instances alternative parts are not only of as good a quality but are often the same sorts of parts but with a different label.

The PSA will be embarking on a campaign with industry and insurers in order to try to minimise the price impact of this sort of barrier. As I have said, it will be taking up these matters with both insurers and motorist organisations. It will also take up with motorist organisations, and once again consumer affairs agencies in this instance, the need for a greater understanding of the status of non-genuine parts in relation to vehicle warranty terms and conditions. That is another part of this barrier towards greater competition in industry. It should also be stated that the PSA will continue an oversight of pricing policies of major suppliers in this area.

There has already been some indication of a betterment in the industry. For the four months from November 1987-arising from a survey of repair parts reported in the computer quote system of the National Roads and Motorists Association-there has been a fall in prices of between 7 per cent and 27 per cent of some items in the whole range of spare part goods. The Government has expressed its concern in this area, and will continue, through the Prices Surveillance Authority, to take an interest in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I preface my question by noting that everyone in Australia is aware that the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU)-the de facto government-determined the direction of tax reform late at night in a Canberra motel room. Are we now to understand that the privatisation direction, so ably spelt out recently by Senator Walsh, has yet again been torpedoed by the ACTU, but this time from a motel room on the Gold Coast arranged by Mr Eddie Kornhauser?
—No, honourable senators are not to understand that. I will not dignify such a squalid little question with any further answer.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to an article in yesterday's Australian Financial Review entitled `Tokyo in favour of US beef'. In that article Japanese Ministers admitted that United States beef imports had been given a preference over beef imports from Australia. It also suggested that Japan might end its present quota scheme in favour of a range of tariffs. Will the Government take all the necessary steps to encourage the Japanese to end their quota system and to end the covert Japanese administrative preference for United States beef?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to that question is yes, of course we will. But I am glad that Senator Foreman has asked this question because it gives me an opportunity to say that the work of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy over the last five years is at last being rewarded. We have in John Kerin one of the best primary industry Ministers that this country has ever had. He has worked persistently and hard over the five years of his tenure of office to try to open up Japanese and European markets. At last we are beginning to see that his perseverance and efforts are justified.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of articles in the Australian Press-I think that they appeared in the Australian Financial Review and the Sydney Morning Herald on about 19 May-reporting comments by Mr Koichi Kato, who is a leading member of the Japanese Diet. I think that he is the Chairman of the primary industry committee of the Liberal Democratic Party-or certainly an influential member of it. He is a member of the Japanese Diet that Mr Kerin visited just last month when he went to Japan to talk about beef quotas and other matters. He has said, in what I think was a beautiful euphemistic phrase, that the Japanese have used `administrative guidance'-that is a lovely term-to increase the United States share of the Japanese beef market at Australia's expense.

The Australian Embassy in Tokyo is following up the full text of what Mr Koichi Kato has said and getting comments from him on the detail, but the admission of `administrative guidance' is, in terms of the effort we have put into the Japanese market, a significant admission. It is the first time that a senior Japanese politician has confirmed what we have been maintaining all along, that there is some interference in terms of that market. It is not an open and free market. That flies in the face of discussions we have had until now with Japanese Ministers and officials who have refused to acknowledge that there is any bias in the system. Australian beef presently is being discriminated against in Japan in at least three ways.

TALK.START.PARA: —And your Government is doing nothing to protect the producer.

—That is a very odd interjection from the honourable senator because I have just spent the first part of the answer to this question demonstrating that we are at last succeeding with the perseverance we have put into that market. If the honourable senator wants to take the argument further, which government, his or ours, formed the Cairns Group to try to liberate world trade in agricultural products? It was ours. So the honourable senator should not interject against us and say in a blanket and unforgiving way that we have done nothing. We have the score on the board. Those opposite did not do it; we did. Let us go back to how Australian beef is discriminated against, because it is important for the Senate to appreciate that there are three major forms of discrimination. The first is in the allocation of quotas. In the previous beef agreements, which expired on 31 March 1988, 6,900 tonnes of the proposed 9,000 tonnes annual increase in quotas-that is, almost 80 per cent-were to be allocated to grain fed beef, in which the United States of America (USA) specialises. On that basis there is a clear case of discrimination.

ANSWER.PARA: We are also discriminated against in the administration of the quotas. Quota arrangements such as the simultaneous buying and selling system and the demand development quota have been designed to give effect to the arbitrary split of quotas in favour of grain fed beef. By contrast, access for chilled beef-Australia's premium product in Japan-has not been permitted to increase. The third method is that rapidly increasing imports of diaphragm beef are, out of quota, classified as offal. This is supplied mainly by the USA and competes directly with some of the beef supplied by Australia, which is restrained under the quota. It is because of the inherent discrimination that the Government has been pressing for the liberalisation of the Japanese beef market so that normal market forces and not Japanese bureaucrats will determine the types and qualities of beef that Japanese consumers will eat.

The USA, of course, is also seeking the liberalisation of the Japanese beef market. To date, bilateral discussions between Australia and Japan, and the USA and Japan, have not produced a satisfactory solution. Both Australia and the USA have taken the matter up under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and panels have been established to examine the conformity of Japan's beef import regime with its GATT obligations. The Government would prefer to resolve this issue through bilateral negotiations and further rounds are to be held to this end. If not, we are resolved to continue in the GATT with our actions. I congratulate Senator Foreman. His question gives me the opportunity to point out that five years of perseverance by John Kerin is beginning, at least in the Japanese market, to pay off.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Is it not a fact that the Government has engaged the Drake organisation to provide a computer training course for Aborigines at a fee of $721 per student per week, for a six-week course, in Queensland and a number of other Australian States? Is it not a fact that other training organisations have indicated publicly that they can provide this service at one-tenth of the cost and that, under the Australian traineeship scheme, fee costs of around $100 to $110 per week were paid for computer training courses similar to those being given by Drake? Why were tenders to provide this service not called by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs? Does this not give further support to the points made by Senator Stone and Senator Crichton-Browne this morning, in the Estimates debate, about the maladministration of the Department?

—The private sector, I am informed, has had a poor record in placing Aboriginal people in employment once the training subsidies run out. The Miller Committee of Review of Aboriginal Employment and Training Programs, honourable senators will recall, was very critical of industry and governments in that regard. The Drake Aboriginal preparation for employment program is a pilot program incorporating job search and post-payment support services, individual counselling and support, cross-cultural understanding, intensive personal development, communication and presentation skills, office procedures and keyboard and word processing skills. Drake has agreed to use its job placement experience to seek real employment outcomes for Aboriginal trainees. Evaluation of the pilot program will include the costs of providing a similar integrated service through other training providers. Employment outcomes will also be monitored and the Government welcomes the involvement of industry in a serious effort to improve its Aboriginal employment record. That brief outline of the program offered by Drake training does not answer the specific questions as to the cost per person per week of training those Aboriginals who will participate in the scheme and I have no information on the comparative figures that Senator MacGibbon put forward. But I will undertake to seek further information from the Minister on the precise funding details.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr Deputy President. None of the services provided by Drake in that statement by the Minister are beyond the powers of other sectors of the community to provide. Why were tenders not called for this service?

—I do not know what the procedure was leading up to the selection of Drake for this particularly important program. As I say, I will inquire and find out what procedures led to the selection of Drake. I will also make inquiries as to comparative costs.

—Has the Minister for Finance seen yesterday's statement by the new President of the National Farmers Federation (NFF) seeking increases in road funding? Will the Government accede to the National Farmers Federation representations on road funding?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of the question is yes. The answer to the second part is that it is extremely difficult to accede to the National Farmers Federation representations on road funding because it all depends on which representation we want to take seriously. Yesterday, an NFF statement was put out, as Senator Schacht said. The first line said:

ANSWER.PARA: The National Farmers' Federation has called for a major increase in Federal Government spending on roads.

That was yesterday; but on 30 April last year the National Farmers Federation issued another document which called for over $11 billion in spending cuts at all levels of government in the May financial statement and the August Budget. The NFF was also kind enough to include a detailed list of the source of these $11 billion-worth of spending cuts, which included a demand that $128m be cut off Federal road funding. So honourable senators can see the difficulty this Government has in acceding to National Farmers Federation representations, because we do not really know whether we should take last year's representation or this year's representation seriously or whether the issuing of the Press statement yesterday automatically means, as Ronald Ziegler used to say, that last year's statement is inoperative-in other words, `We were fibbing before'. It is also worth noting that the ultimate author of last year's National Farmers Federation statement was Andrew Robb who has since come out of the political closet, so to speak, and joined the staff of the Liberal Party of Australia, where I trust he is occupied in the same sort of exercise as an employee of the Liberal Party as he was as an employee of the National Farmers Federation; that is, getting written into Liberal Party policy that $10 billion, $11 billion or $13 billion will be cut off Federal Government outlays. It is not coincidental--

TALK.START.PARA: —You would not be opposed to that, would you?

—Yes, I would be opposed to that. I know that Senator Stone and some of his supporters, financial conjurers, would introduce a bit of cosmetics into government accounting and cut billions of dollars off what are called government outlays by converting government outlays to private outlays-through the Medicare system or health policy. The effect of that, of course, would be to increase the total expenditure on health for no better outcome. The Opposition would also reduce government outlays, I have no doubt, by hiding them as tax expenditures instead of being honest about them and acknowledging them as government outlays. That was a trick that was widely employed by the Fraser Government and by John Howard during his period as Treasurer, although I expect that Senator Stone would have advised against it in his former incarnation-I do not think it would be unfair to say-as a public servant who never doubted his own infallibility. At least he had at that time some intellectual integrity, an attribute which I regret to say he seems to have shed since becoming a politician. Even though Senator Stone was nearly always wrong--
—Mr Deputy President--
—You had to think about this one, didn't you?

—In taking a point of order I note the interjection from the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. If one took a point of order every time that Senator Walsh was rude, crude and obnoxious, we would not have any debate in this place at all. I ask him to withdraw that last reference to Senator Stone.
—The remark was out of order, Senator Walsh. You should withdraw it.

—I withdraw it, Mr Deputy President. But as I said, Mr Andrew Robb, who was the author of last year's NFF document, is now working for the Liberal Party. He might be able to assist the Liberal Party in actually getting together a list of figures that add up to $11 billion, as he did last year. But he is not likely to provide any guarantee that there will not be errors of fact as well as errors of omission, as there were of course in the Liberal Party's documentation last year. For example, in Mr Robb's effort last year he had as a saving $577m from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service, which was in fact more than the total expenditure on the ABC and the SBS. So Mr Robb might help flesh out a few details, but his record indicates that he is no more likely to get the arithmetic right than whoever his predecessor was who drew up the incomplete list of Liberal Party spending cuts--
—Was he one of the Young Liberals in the courtyard?

—No, I think he is a bit old for a Young Liberal. I understand that the typical Young Liberal in the Australian Capital Territory-and my source for this comes from within the Liberal Party-has a physical age of 19 and a mental age of 15. In conclusion, the Government will look at the National Farmers Federation representations, as it looks at all representations, but we are really very confused about what we should do about them.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Can the Minister overcome the following problem found by voluntary organisations who send aid, in the form of clothing, to mission hospitals in India and Kashmir? A report from one such organisation states that it sent 14 parcels to its three outlets in India and Kashmir, but unfortunately those groups were charged exorbitant customs duties by the Indian authorities. As these groups were unable to pay, as they work on a shoe-string, the parcels have had to be refused and returned. As the voluntary organisation had to pay $168 to Australia Post to get the parcels to India, it was unable to pay the customs duty. Would it be possible for negotiations between the authorities of India and Australia to overcome the problem?
—I will have to take that question on notice. If Senator Walters has any further information on the specific case, I would be grateful if she would give it to my office.

—My question is also directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, and it relates to the situation in Sri Lanka. Is the Minister aware of the recent statement by opposition parties in Sri Lanka concerning human rights in that country? Does the Government share the concern expressed in that statement concerning the detention of political prisoners under the Prevention of Terrorism Act and under emergency regulations? In the light of the Government's proper expressions of concern with regard to human rights in other countries in our region, will the Government support the call for the release of political prisoners in Sri Lanka, or at least for the public gazettal of the names of all those who have been detained under the Prevention of Terrorism Act and the emergency regulations, with a statement of the reasons for their arrest or detention?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government is aware of the concern expressed about the human rights situation in Sri Lanka by many segments of the Sri Lankan community, including the opposition parties in that country. On the question of the detention of political prisoners under the Prevention of Terrorism Act and associated emergency regulations, the Australian Government has in fact frequently expressed its concern to the Sri Lankan Government, stressing our wish that the political prisoners should be released or properly charged and brought to trial. That of course remains our position.

ANSWER.PARA: We welcomed the Indo-Sri Lankan peace accord, not least because of the elements in it directed at improving the human rights situation in Sri Lanka. In the period immediately following the signing of the accord, a significant number of people who had been detained under the Prevention of Terrorism Act and other emergency regulations were released. More recently we have noted the release of a further number of detainees, including some whose cases had been followed by the Australian Government on an individual basis. The Australian Government regrets that the continuing incidence of violence provoked by groups determined to destroy the accord are hindering its implementation and the return to normality in Sri Lanka. We certainly call again, as we have in the past, on all parties in Sri Lanka to recognise the accord and work to ensure its implementation and the protection of human rights of all Sri Lankans.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BRISBANE AIRPORT: PROPOSED NEW INTERNATIONAL TERMINAL

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. In view of the fact that the 1981 Joint Committee on Public Works deferred the construction of the new international airport in Brisbane until the 1990s, based on projected international passenger numbers in 1986-87 of 500,000, and that the actual passenger numbers for that year topped 900,000, in addition to which the present terminal is little more than an old tin shed, which creates a very bad impression on overseas visitors, has the Government any plans to bring forward the commencement date for the construction of a new international airport terminal in Brisbane? Is the Minister aware that the Queensland Government has offered to make funds available, provided the Federal Government does likewise, to hasten the commencement of construction of the new international terminal in Brisbane, which is very badly needed to cope with the influx of overseas visitors to Brisbane for World Expo 88?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Queensland Government is always very generous in dealing with other people's money, as Senator Bjelke-Petersen would be well aware, but I do understand that the Queensland Premier is offering to contribute towards the cost of a new international terminal at Brisbane Airport. I am also advised that the Federal Airports Corporation, the FAC, has had preliminary discussions with Qantas Airways Ltd as to future terminal needs at Brisbane, and I am sure that the Corporation would welcome discussion with the State Government as to funding arrangements for any future facilities.

ANSWER.PARA: The existing international terminal has recently been upgraded to provide improved passenger handling facilities. Its current capacity does provide for the handling of two B747 aircraft in an hour, and this is well in excess of the reported 350-passenger limit which was mentioned by the Queensland Premier. On present forecasts the terminal will cater for international traffic at Brisbane, albeit not very satisfactorily, until the early 1990s. While the international terminal is an older facility, it is also worth acknowledging that it is part of, albeit a somewhat distant part of, an ultra-modern new airport complex of world standard, and as such we do consider that the new airport will play a positive role in Queensland's economic development. It certainly ought to-it has cost enough money.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY: POLICE INVESTIGATION OF SEXUAL OFFENCES

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

It will be under the command of an experienced detective sergeant, Fiona Crombie, and it will be staffed initially by six officers with relevant experience who have received specialist training in the investigations of sexual offences and the needs of the victims of such crimes. It is planned to have the unit fully operational on 25 July 1988. It will be established in discreet premises away from normal police stations in order to afford the victims maximum privacy. The premises will also provide victims with an essential supportive and professional environment. The unit will work closely with both community groups and other police services in undertaking the highly sensitive and personal investigations with which it is to be charged.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 May Senator Messner asked me a series of questions relating to interests held by companies associated with Mr Murdoch in Northern Star Holdings. I am pleased to be able to give him an answer, which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

On 19 May 1988, Senator Messner asked a series of questions related to interests held by companies associated with Mr Murdoch in Northern Star Holdings (Network Ten). Mr Macphee asked a similar question of Mr Morris in the House of Representatives. These questions were apparently based on access to a departmental minute to me, dated 23 November 1987, related to prescribed interest levels.

At the outset, I should point out that the relevant authority for the administration and enforcement of the provision of the Broadcasting act in these matters is the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT).

Under the Broadcasting Act. the ABT must approve the acquisition of, or increase in, a prescribed interest in a broadcasting licence. A shareholding of more than 5 per cent in television is a prescribed interest.

The transactions at the centre of Senator Messner's question, i.e. acquisition of the Ten network stations by Northern Star Holdings, is presently subject to an inquiry by the ABT. The inquiry is also related to the acquisition of a major interest in Northern Star by subsidiaries of Westfield Capital Corporation and interests associated with Daily Mail and General Trust, Associated Newspaper Holdings Pty Ltd and by News Investment (Australia) Pty Ltd. The precise level of interest which the News Corporation group and the Associated Newspaper Holdings group have in Northern Star Holdings will be considered in this inquiry. The Tribunal expects to invite further submissions in relation to the inquiry within the next two weeks.

To the extent that there may have been-as of November of last year-a breach of the 15 per cent maximum foreign ownership provisions (as the minute indicates but which Senator Messner does not quote), this was immediately brought to the attention of the appropriate authority, i.e. the ABT. On present information available to the ABT, the News holding in Northern Star does not in fact exceed the 15 per cent foreign ownership threshold, whatever the position may have been at some time in the past.

As to Senator Messner's assertion that News is in breach of the cross-media provisions, no breach can occur until the expiry of the minimum six-month period of grace, which begins on the date the ABT proves the relevant transaction. That approval has not yet occurred, as the inquiry is still in progress.

If the ABT finds that a breach of the foreign ownership provisions of the Broadcasting Act has occurred at any time, it can take this into account in deciding whether to approve the transaction. The current laws relating to approval of share transactions in broadcasting licences, including the period of grace provisions, were the responsibility of the Fraser Government in 1981, of which both Senator Messner and Mr Macphee were Ministers.

Although the Director of Public Prosecutions has a discretionary power to prosecute an apparent breach of the ownership and control provisions of the Act, there has never been such a prosecution launched by any Government.
