Of course, as the Senate is aware, I have initiated a wide ranging review of the Broadcasting Act, including its sanctions, provisions and the role of the ABT, with the aim of ensuring that the legislation is appropriate to current circumstances and that the ABT can perform its role with maximum effectiveness.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters have leave to meet during the sitting of the Senate on Monday, 23 May 1988, for the purpose of hearing evidence in public session.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Chaney proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's sell-out of Australian consumers and taxpayers by its craven capitulation to the trade unions and party machine on the privatisation issue.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Opposition has brought forward for discussion as a matter of public importance the Government's sell-out of Australian consumers and taxpayers by its craven capitulation to the trade unions and party machine on the privatisation issue. We have done so because what was announced by Senator Evans yesterday, namely, the acceptance by the Government of its inability to change the Australian Labor Party's policy with respect to privatisation at the National Conference, is an extraordinary setback for Australia in terms of its capacity to meet the challenges which we face.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no doubt that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), who is at the table, will recall that when he was made mega-Minister for Transport and Communications we discussed the challenges which he faced in reforming areas of the Australian economy which contained notorious inefficiencies. Today's position is that the Government has effectively stepped back and indicated that it is not capable of meeting some of the significant challenges it has in this vital area, particularly in the area which is administered by Senator Evans.

One should start this debate remembering the basic facts which have to underpin our consideration of every policy matter in this chamber. Australia is a country with high and increasing foreign debt. It has suffered reduced living standards and does not appear to have the capacity to lift them. Questions of economic efficiency are not matters which are abstruse, obscure or of no interest to the men and women of Australia. The men and women of Australia have seen the results of our economic decline and have felt them in their daily living and in their incapacity to maintain the living standards to which they have been accustomed.

The other reason for bringing this matter on for debate is that it is another significant example that nothing in the Labor Party has changed. The Labor Party is not able to make critical decisions because of its subservience to the trade union movement and to its party organisation. The people of Australia, the people out there who are dubbed `ordinary Australians' by the Labor Party, are extremely worried about the Government's relationship with big business and the trade unions. This is just the latest example of the extent to which the trade unions are calling the shots with this Government. In Queensland yesterday, Mr Crean said--

TALK.START.PARA: —Simon says, eh?

—What Simon said was that the privatisation debate is finished, that as an issue it is dead. Simon Crean has pronounced the privatisation issue dead. That is no unique thing. Last year one of the senior Ministers in this Government, Mr Willis, had some very interesting things to say about the imbalance in the industrial arbitration system in this country. He made the point in the House of Representatives just last May that one could not have an industrial relations system where only one side of the bargain was bound. He said that one had to have the capacity to bind the trade unions as well as the employers. He went into Parliament and said that he would introduce new laws that would ensure that trade unions were subject to the directions of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. When he was on radio with me in Melbourne in June, after he had withdrawn that Bill because of the election, he repeated the fact that he as Minister for Industrial Relations would introduce legislation which contained a direction system which would be much more effective than the current bans clause which has been moribund for 20 years. Mr Willis has made very clear statements both in the Parliament and in the media about what should be done to reform our industrial relations system.

SPEECH.PARA: A funny thing happened on the way to the Parliament, because Simon popped up again. Simon Crean made a statement on 17 August. He said:
They-
and by `they' he meant the Government of which Senator Evans and Mr Willis are part-
can still introduce a Bill but it will have to be one which does not do anything on compliance.

What happened? Two weeks ago Mr Willis introduced his legislation into the House of Representatives. Is anyone vaguely surprised that that legislation contains no provision for compliance of the sort that Mr Willis had outlined? Once again, the trade union movement, through its leader Mr Simon Crean of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), had spoken and the Government, of course, responded.

I will not go into as much detail, but I simply remind the Senate and the people of Australia what happened to the Government's tax reform proposals. Remember the Taxation Summit? Remember how the representatives of the people of Australia were gathered together here to discuss what sort of tax system we should have? The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was hauled off to a motel room by the ACTU and given his marching orders. The shape of the Labor Party's taxation system was determined not in this Parliament, not in the parliamentary Labor Party, but by ACTU direction. I ask the question: Is this a government for all of the people of Australia?
Opposition senators-Never!

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer has just been given by Liberal and National Party senators. This is not a government for all of the people of Australia. This is a government for those people who are the friends of this Government, and no-one else. In the limited time we have for debate on a matter of public importance, I want to make a series of points about where we have arrived at in this privatisation debate. First, it is quite clear that the Government is not facing up to our economic problems. The Government's own spokesmen have made it quite clear that the use of privatisation as one of the tools to obtain greater efficiency in the Australian economy is a matter of considerable importance. In the same way, Government spokesmen have made it quite clear that the people of Australia, both as taxpayers and consumers, required the option of the privatisation of public enterprises because that would be in their interests.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has wasted a chance which was offered to it by the Opposition of having an effective bipartisan policy in this area. One of the pathetic things about this debate is that as recently as today the Government accused us of being ideological on this issue. In fact, in 1986 we published our policy on privatisation for all to see. That policy is completely in accord with the views which have recently been expressed by the Prime Minister, Senator Evans and Senator Walsh. They are not even capable of picking up this policy and running with it when they have the full support of the Opposition. This is because they are frightened of the trade union movement.

Finally, the really extraordinary thing about this debate is that it has been ruined by the Labor Party. Senator Evans and his colleagues have poisoned the well of this debate. They have used the issue of privatisation for the most short term political reasons. They have poisoned the well of debate within the Australian Labor Party itself. During this debate I will quote some of the things that have been said by the Prime Minister and Mr Keating which are totally at variance with their more recent views, statements which were made simply to cast fear in the hearts of government employees and to try to wring a few votes out of an electorate which was so easily frightened at that time. We have here a very sorry situation, a situation where the interests of the people of Australia have been sold down the river by this Government for short term political purposes. Now the Government is hoist with its own petard.

In looking at the relevance of the issue of privatisation to the welfare of the people of Australia, it has been made amply clear by the documents which have been brought into this Parliament by the Government itself over recent weeks that at the heart of getting a more efficient economy which will better serve the people of Australia is the issue of having more competition within the economy. The farmers of Australia, who are having better times at the moment because prices for their products have improved and in many areas seasonal conditions are good, have gone through lean and difficult years. Wheat farmers in Senator Panizza's area, for example, have been hard hit by the rising costs. If we look at the report of the Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport we find the statement by a royal commissioner that wheat farmers have been cost up to $10 per tonne because they do not have competitive systems of transport for their wheat. The tens of thousands of farmers around Australia who have suffered difficulties over recent years have suffered because of a lack of competition.

The situation is exactly the same for coastal shipping. The report of the Industries Assistance Commission says exactly the same thing-that the failure to have a competitive shipping system around Australia means that between $300m and $700m a year extra is paid by Australian consumers. These are direct imposts on the people of Australia. They are examples of the gains which can be made for everyone in Australia if this issue of privatisation and encouraging competition within the economy is pursued. In addition, we see the issue of debt reduction as important. The reality is that in an economy which has been burdened enormously with debt by the present Government, the capacity to reduce our debt by asset sales is also of some importance.

There are a few Labor members in the chamber, which is nice, because Labor senators are not normally particularly interested in issues which are of concern to their constituencies. Let me quote what Senator Walsh said when he tackled the great lies which have been part of this debate about public and private ownership. In his final words in a Press release issued by him just a few weeks ago, he said:
The inefficient use of resources has as its inevitable outcome the less effective achievement of social objectives and will therefore cause living standards to decline.

This is not an obscure economic argument; it is an argument which Senator Walsh has said is about causing Australian living standards to decline. The Government has stepped back on an issue which is relevant to Australian living standards. Senator Walsh gave the lie to the sorts of arguments which have affected senators such as the honourable senator who has been caterwauling on the other side and attempting to interject in this debate. I notice that he is not going to contribute to the debate. Senator Burns keeps shouting out because, no doubt, he is a defender of public enterprises. I remind him that Senator Walsh pointed out:
. . . too often public enterprises operated in their own organisational interests and that of their management and employees rather than the public interest.

He said that the publicly-owned airlines `have been a case study in industrial relations management at the expense of the travelling public'. They were not the words of some Liberal; that is what Senator Walsh said. He said that the present airline system is a case study in industrial relations management at the expense of the travelling public. Honourable senators opposite might stand for that sort of thing, but we had hoped that Minister Evans and Minister Walsh would be able to remove such attitudes from the Australian Labor Party and bring it into the twentieth century.

The Minister who is to speak next in this debate has over the last few months made a significant contribution to the public debate on this issue. He has pointed out, either directly or through his agents, that some of the bodies for which he is responsible, in particular the airlines, are in need of another $850m in capital over the next two to three years. Senator Evans as recently as this morning has made it quite clear that there are no easy options to meeting the problems of finding that capital.

The significant point that has to be made is that even though Senator Evans has gone down in defeat, as recently as this morning he was reminding the people of Australia, and no doubt intentionally reminding his own Party, that if we refuse to look at this issue of privatisation we face not the preservation of public assets but their absolute dissolution; we look at their running down and their destruction. Senator Evans was quite explicit about this on the AM program this morning. He admitted that he was depressed. Let me quote him:
. . . as the Minister in charge of the airlines in particular, that they don't become just marginal bitplayers in the aviation scene-that's very depressing from a public enterprise point of view.
He went on to point out:

If the private sector component of our aviation industry should take the market by storm . . . because we are unable to keep pace in the international aviation scene, it is even more depressing because not just will there be an element of privatisation by default, as other foreign, privately owned airlines pick up the gaps, but obviously we will be losing a major economic advantage . . .

Senator Evans was reminding his own constituency, although he was unable to carry his view, that the Australian Labor Party is pursuing policies which will destroy the existing public enterprises in this country rather than turn them into efficient agents for economic growth.

I referred to the fact that the Opposition had over a period of years offered the Government the opportunity to develop its policies in this area without difficulty being created at the political level. The fact of the matter is that as long ago as 1986 we published in a document entitled Policies for Business what we described as the principles of privatisation. I want to quote briefly from that paper because these principles have been reiterated by the Opposition consistently since then and most recently in detail by our Leader, John Howard, in March of this year. In 1986 we said:

The fundamental principle underlying a policy that returns functions from the public to the private sector is that competition ensures better and more efficient delivery of goods and services to consumers than centralised decision-making under government ownership.

That has been amply proved as a statement of fact by the recent report of the Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport and the Industries Assistance Commission report on coastal shipping. We went on to talk about the need to have a more efficient and competitive economy, and we set out the guiding principles that would govern our approach. The first principle was that there must be demonstrable benefits to consumers and/or taxpayers, and every decision we have made to advocate privatisation of any particular enterprise has met that test.

We talked about the need for gradual implementation. We talked about the fact that it is not to be a bargain basement sale but a commitment to reverse decades of public sector growth and accompanying inefficiency. We talked about the protection of the situation of the existing employees and giving them preferential access to shares to assist in increasing productivity and industrial harmony. We talked about the protection of remote areas, a commitment from which we have never resiled. We talked not simply about trying to puff up the capital value of the asset, not having a sale for the purpose of getting an immediate capital return, but rather about trying to ensure that the enterprises are sold in a way which will enhance competition rather than retain monopoly rights. We talked about our timing of these transfers of ownership to avoid disrupting capital markets and we talked about encouraging small investors to get a share in these great enterprises. We talked about using the funds not to finance government expenditure but to reduce accumulated public debt, and we said that where government ownership was retained it would be subject to the same conditions as private enterprise, especially with respect to taxation, superannuation, capital raising and accounting requirements.

In other words, we did anything but adopt an ideological stance. We adopted a stance which was aimed at achieving greater efficiencies in the economy and greater benefits for Australian consumers and taxpayers. In that sense we had a brief period of hope when Senator Evans,Senator Walsh, the Prime Minister and Senator Button, after years of cynically bucketing the concept of privatisation for short term political gain, became temporary proponents of privatisation as a tool for chasing economic efficiency.

The Labor Party, by its cynicism and destructive approach to this debate, as I said in opening, has poisoned the well. It has been as cynical and inconsistent in this as it has in its approach to uranium mining and to the Aboriginal people of Australia. It has brought short term political advantages at a cost to a reasonable long term debate and a reasonable long term approach. This is an area in which the Government stands most condemned. Privatisation, brought about in a careful way and in accordance with the principles that we outlined as long ago as 1986, could benefit the people of Australia. We now have a situation where the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and the most troglodyte elements of the ALP in Canberra have combined to absolutely destroy the Government's current moves towards our Liberal and National Party policy in this area. We deeply regret that. We hope that the Minister in his response in this debate will show some of the courage that prevailed in part of his presentation on this issue, that he will put the argument for privatisation of these great national enterprises and that we will see him showing a little more resolve than he showed after his rather demeaning backdown in front of Mr Simon Crean yesterday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me begin by offering a little reciprocal homily to Senator Chaney on the subject of the labour movement, because it did feature so prominently in the crocodile tear-stained harangue we have just heard from him. The Australian Labor Party is a very different animal from that of the Liberal Party of Australia. Thank God for the health and decency of this country that that is so. One of the things that make us different is the emphasis that we place on careful policy development. We have placed emphasis on the machinery to ensure the par-ticipation in that process of the whole, broad labour movement. One of the things that make us different is the primacy that we give to the biennial Labor Party National Conference in determining fundamental party policy positions. That, of course, stands in spectacular contrast to the situation in the Liberal Party, where--
—Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Does the Minister say that the broad labour movement is sitting behind him now?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Our policy making process is in spectacular contrast to that which applies opposite, where the parliamentary party treats Federal National Council of the Liberal Party resolutions with exactly the same contempt as the leading members of that National Council now regard the parliamentary party opposite. There is a fundamental and very stark difference between the processes of the two parties. Where major policy issues involving traditionally sensitive nerves, such as the future of public enterprise, come forward, policy-making through our party processes can be a protracted process, and sometimes a frustratingly protracted process. As the old slogan goes: the difficult things can be done quickly but the impossible things sometimes take a little longer. This state of affairs may appear to be a somewhat burdensome restriction for Labor governments to live with, and in a sense it is-not least in the fast-moving kind of policy environment with which Labor governments have to contend these days. The important point I want to make is this-and it is an important point-this is a constraint with which all Labor governments have lived. It is a crucial part of the cement which keeps the whole labour movement-parliamentary and extra-parliamentary-together. It is one of the reasons why our Party, unlike its succession of conservative opponents over the decades, has not only survived but also gone from strength to strength in nearly 100 years of continuous existence. Cohesion, strength and discipline are the hallmark of this particular Party in government. They are the hallmark of this Labor Government's relationship with its own movement, as exemplified nowhere more starkly, dramatically or importantly than in the continuing success of the prices and incomes accord that the Labor Government has entered into with the trade union movement. It is simply the most successful prices and incomes policy that has ever been achieved or maintained by any government anywhere in the world. The Labor Party cohesion and the labour movement cohesion in this respect stand out like a beacon in contrast to the disorganised shamble that confronts us daily in the Parliament and in the media.

SPEECH.PARA: To be lectured today as we have been by a Liberal Party and a coalition Opposition which tore themselves to pieces so visibly in the run-up to the last election-do honourable senators opposite remember that; they are silent about that now-which have continued to tear themselves to pieces so visibly and so dramatically over issues such as tax policy and media ownership policy in recent years, which have no coherence discipline, and, above all, no confidence in their leadership is really a breathtaking piece of cheek. I mentioned in Question Time today the particular difficulties that Mr Howard has been having in demonstrating cohesion, coherence and leadership. Let me mention them again because the events of the last two or three weeks are very embarrassing for honourable senators to recall.

Honourable senators will recall the circumstances in which their Leader was rolled on media policy by his shadow Cabinet; the circumstances in which their Leader has been rolled on the referendums by his Party room; the circumstances in which their Leader has been rolled on the question of parliamentary department legislation by his own senators here and the circumstances in which he has been rolled on Aboriginal land rights, once again by the rednecks in his own Party room. Honourable senators opposite have a leader who tacks up on his bed every night the Bonar Law slogan because it is the only one he can rely on, the only one that makes sense. Bonar Law said on that famous occasion, `I must follow them because I am their leader'.

This situation we confront is not one about which there is any sensible policy formulation going on in the Opposition benches in between all these alarms, diversions, retreats and forays by the Liberal Party Duke of Plaza-Toro over there who leads his followers from behind. The Liberal Party's own privatisation policy, if it can be dignified with that description, has oscillated wildly over recent years between a condition of total muddle and dither on the one hand and what can only be described as crazy bravery on the other hand. I will give honourable senators some chapter and verse in support of those two propositions. On the muddle and dither side of it, I cannot think of any better demonstration than the evolution, if it can be so described, of the Opposition policy on telecommunications. I point out for the umpteenth time in passing that it was never considered by anyone in the labour movement that Telecom Australia was a candidate for privatisation in any form. That was spelt out nowhere more clearly, for example, than by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 9 September last year.

Let us compare by contrast the Liberal Party position on Telecom. On 28 August 1985 the then Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, in a speech to the National Press Club, said that the coalition had not yet made up its mind whether in government it would privatise Telecom. Mr Howard was clearly captivated, however, by what he described as the remark-ably successful sale of British Telecom. Of course, that sale has produced somewhat less than stunning results prompting, among other criticisms, Britain's National Consumer Council recently to award British Telecom the title of the nation's worst public service. By the middle of last year, however, Mr Howard had apparently managed to make up his mind. In an interview with Derryn Hinch on 9 July he said, `Telecom is not going to be privatised or sold'. He apparently failed, however, to let his Deputy, Mr Peacock, in on this secret. In an interview with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in Adelaide on 29 January this year, Mr Peacock was asked about privatising Telecom and he replied:
Well, we will want to break it up.

As Mick Young used to say, `Andrew always seems to dry out as he moves towards the Nullarbor'. Meanwhile the various lesser lights of the Opposition have been running around excitedly, spewing forth a variety of usually conflicting Press statements in a vain attempt to keep themselves and everybody else awake. We have had the Opposition spokesman on small business and consumer affairs, Mr Moore-I think he is still the spokesman; I cannot recall, we have not heard much from him-busily writing to the Sydney Morning Herald on 15 January expressing the opinion that if Telecom was having difficulty in expanding its network it was time the private sector had a go. That was the Opposition's front bench spokesman in January this year.

Then Senator Alston in a Press statement late last year-I cannot tell honourable senators when because he was not sufficiently organised to put a date on it-called for the immediate scrapping of Telecom's existing cross-subsidisation arrangements. He did not elaborate on how his compatriots in the National Party should deal with the calls of outrage that could reasonably be expected from constituents once the people in the bush realised that scrapping the present metropolitan subsidisation of the rural telephone network would expose them to phone installation costs and phone bills running, of course, into thousands of dollars.

Then, of course, let us not forget poor old Senator Messner, single-handedly responsible for the destruction of God knows how many trees as he pours out his own set of Press releases and as he wallows along, to mix the metaphor, in the wake of the rest of the outfit. He took about only two months after Senator Alston's statement to decide that a coalition government would retain the cross-subsidies. We can only assume that he cleared this with Mr Howard who, back in his National Press Club speech, was attacking the concept of cross-subsidisation. I know it hurts honourable senators opposite, but it is a shambles. It is a dither; it is a muddle. That is the point that I am making and it is dramatically made by these sorts of conflicting positions that have emerged.

Both Howard and Messner have run the line that Telecom should not be afforded any pricing flexibility while it retains its monopoly. As was pointed out by Anne Davies in the Australian Financial Review on 21 January, implicit in this statement is support for competition on the basic telephone network. That is a move that would obviously leave Telecom unable to meet its community service obligations and expose Australians outside the metropolitan areas again to greatly increased costs.

So there we have had it over and over again-muddle, confusion and chaos. But that is only one side of the picture. On the other side the Liberals' attitude to privatisation, the Opposition's attitude, has been the phenomenon that can be described only as crazy bravery. This is the list as it now appears in the recent run of policy statements that have appeared--

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your attitude?

—I will come to that in a moment. I have a list of the things that those opposite now say they want to privatise, not just to some small extent to enable public sector enterprise to continue in the ring in the way that Senator Chaney was suggesting was an admirable state of affairs halfway through his speech. That is the point at which he really started to drown in crocodile tears. The situation for members of the Opposition is that they want apparently, according to their various recent policy releases, to sell off the following: 100 per cent of Australian Airlines; 100 per cent of Qantas Airways Ltd; 100 per cent of Aussat, although that will obviously be over Ian Macphee's dead body, as he has made clear with a succession of recent Press statements; 100 per cent of the domestic and international airline terminals; 100 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank; 100 per cent of the Australian Industry Development Corporation; 100 per cent of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation; 100 per cent of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation; 100 per cent of Medibank Private; 100 per cent of the national Pipeline Authority; 100 per cent of the Australian National Line; and, in a fit of moderation, 49 per cent of the Overseas Telecommunications Commission. That has not been preceded by any visible process of policy formulation.

SPEECH.PARA: Where is the argument? Where is the analysis? Where is the reasoning of the pros and cons that have preceded and led up to those particular sets of policy commitments if, indeed, such as they are? Where is the consideration of whether the capital market in this country could possibly absorb the floods of floats that would be involved in any attempt to implement over any kind of credible time span a set of objectives of that particular kind? What we have got here is nothing more and nothing less than an ideological binge. That is the only way that honourable senators opposite know how to approach policy making. It is an ideological orgy. They have an ideological `la grande bouffe' approach to the business of policy-making. They have no other way of approaching the policy formulation process-no more articulate or credible way of approaching it-than to reach over, grab a bag of chocolates and stuff them down their collective throat, all in one big go, without any understanding or appreciation of the process of analysis and the process of digestion that is involved in a rational policy making regime.

What has been the Government's approach and my approach, by contrast, to the position of public enterprises in this country? I will tell honourable senators opposite what my approach and the Government's approach is. I am very happy to do so. It is an approach which recognises that there are two quite separate and distinct issues that arise when one is considering the future of public enterprises in this country.

The first question which is sometimes called an issue of privatisation-but I think, as Senator Button said in Question Time today, that is a misnomer-is that of the efficiency and accountability of the enterprises and organisations in question. That is an issue which is tremendously important to the future of public sector enterprise and it is one which this Government has been systematically addressing from its very first days in office. It is a matter that came very fully to public and parliamentary attention with the publication by Senator Walsh of the White Paper late last year. It is a policy commitment and an approach that will come very fully to fruition next week with the major statement that I will make in this place on the future of Government business enterprises so far as their financial and corporate structures are concerned; so far as questions of planning and accountability are concerned; and so far as major strategic controls such as superannuation and executive remuneration, borrowing controls, industrial relations coordination and so on are concerned. It is a statement that will address the desirability or otherwise of maintaining the mass of day to day controls which have been built up over so many years of tory government allegedly committed to rational public administration and sensible competition, and which it did nothing to undermine during its period in office, any more than it did with airline regulation or oil regulation. Next week's statement will address all of those issues in a very systematic and detailed way.

The other problem concerning public sector enterprises is the problem of capital formation. That is the problem which does raise as a possible solution to the full or partial selling off of such organisations the question of the injection of private equity. Obviously, that is a much more difficult question to confront. It is necessarily a question that we have had to confront in an evolutionary way.

My impetus in addressing this particular question has not been, and never will be, ideological in character or content. It is an approach to the problem which is stimulated, motivated, governed and which continues to be driven by me and the Government's perception of just what and how significant those particular problems are. It is based on an appreciation that these enterprises-some more so than others-do have major capital needs. Their position in the marketplace is such that it will massively and markedly deteriorate if those capital needs are not met. It is a set of problems for which I am readily and cheerfully willing to concede there are no soft options available, in particular the traditionally thought of soft options, of budgetary handouts and further access to the borrowing market. On numerous occasions I have sought-I will not do so again now-to spell out and quantify my perception and the Government's perception of what those particular capital needs are.

The important point that I have stressed and that I will go on stressing in public and internal discussions of this matter in the future is that a failure to come to grips with these capital formation problems will condemn these enterprises to wither on the vine in the sense of becoming holders of a less and less significant share of the particular market in question. It will have significant implications for the future of public enterprise in terms of the domestic market players. Even more than that, it will have significant implications for the balance of payments, foreign revenue earnings and so on when one talks about international players such as Qantas Airways Ltd. That is the truth and the reality of the matter. There are problems.

The final point I would make is that there are many different ways of approaching and confronting those problems. There are other options that need to be explored and I will continue to explore them both privately and publicly. What distinguishes us, yet again, from the barking cacophony, the disorganised, incoherent rabble that confronts us across this Parliament is that we will keep a debate going; we will keep hanging in there to confront and seek solutions to these problems. I am sure that eventually we will find solutions to them. In doing so, I am very sure of one thing: we will be acting infinitely more sensitively and with infinitely more regard to the real needs of the Australian community than could ever be managed by those who so rightly sit on the Opposition benches and who, on the strength of their performance today, will be sitting there for many more years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating a matter of public importance brought forward by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's sell-out of Australian consumers and taxpayers by its craven capitulation to the trade unions and party machine on the privatisation issue.

The first point that needs to be made is that the Australian Labor Party has not abandoned privatisation; it has been put aside for the moment. Very clearly, that is because it cannot get the numbers at present. It is not because the Hawke Ministry does not want to privatise; it is because at the moment it cannot privatise.

On behalf of the Australian Democrats I wish to spell out why my Party strongly supports public enterprises and the value that we see in public enterprises for our society. We do not believe that we should seek to tailor our policies simply to satisfy international bankers and investors. It is the international bankers and investors who are demanding surplus Budgets and a reduction in public sector borrowing requirements. It is that demand for economic stringency imposed from outside Australia that has led both the Liberal and the Labor parties to support privatisation, irrespective of the effects of privatisation on the average Australian. By sheer coincidence, it is also the bankers, financiers and investors who stand to make the profits. Let us look at Australia's situation. In 1986, the view of the then Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, when he spoke to the Royal Australian Institute of Public Administration on privatisation and deregulation was as follows:

Australia has a small public sector and is already highly privatised by international standards. In terms of public expenditure as a proportion of GDP, we rank either 18th or 19th among the 24 OECD countries.

I am sorry to interject some facts into this otherwise fascinating debate today, but that is where Australia stands in the international table. We are already highly privatised. We are already one of the half dozen most highly privatised economies in the Western world. Mr Dawkins went on to quote a variety of examples:

Three-quarters of Canada's airline industry, all of Germany's and Italy's, are state-owned, in comparison to only 25 per cent of Australia's. One quarter of . . . Germany's oil production is state-owned; none of Australia's.
Half of France's and Holland's motor . . . industries are state-owned: none of Australia's.
. . . half of Belgium's . . . France's and Italy's steel industries are state-owned; none of Australia's.
Britain's, France's and Austria's coal industries are . . . state-owned; none of Australia's.

So let us get a bit of perspective as to where Australia stands when we get these rampant and hysterical calls for privatisation, regardless of the value to the community or the individual Australian citizen. There are very good reasons for having public enterprises. Public enterprises can be directed to other than profit-making concerns. My Party is not at all worried by that fact.

We believe that there are multiple purposes to be satisfied within our economy. One purpose is to deliver equal services to those people who have unequal chances. We are able to spend more on those people who, by accident of birth, upbringing, sickness, illness, distress or death in their families, are unable to have the same chances as everybody else in this community. Unequal service provided to unequal people is one of the reasons we have public enterprises. I hope we will always have those public enterprises. I ask Opposition senators and those in the Government who are so rampageously rambo about this exercise, every time they come back to this country from some other country, to express to anybody they might be travelling with, the fact they are returning to the best country in the world. Why is it the best? Because we are willing to share some of our wealth and we do it through our public enterprises.

It is about time somebody started to talk some sense instead of the economic nonsense that is bandied around-that somehow or other the ownership of those companies passing into private hands will suddenly make those industries terribly concerned about our citizens. A private company is there to make profits. It is not there to help the citizens of this country. I am not complaining about that; that is why we have private enterprises. But let us be clear about it: they are not here to help other citizens make a living or get an education or to assist them to do a whole range of other things.

TALK.START.PARA: —They just provide jobs; that is all they do.
—Senator Stone is attacking the profit motive now. He can do that later. I have just expressed my support for the profit motive. Let it be on record that Senator Stone is opposed to it.
—That is totally untrue.

—It is not. Senator Stone should sit down. He will have his time later. He has been rabbiting on for most of the rest of the debate and he wants to take up my time. He should shut up and sit down. Does he want 100 per cent of the time in this Senate?
—Get on with it.

—Senator Bishop should be quiet too. She and Senator Tambling have done nothing but talk to each other about what drinks they will have later. They have already had a lovely lunch, as we heard in the last debate. Now they are talking about having some more. One of the other multipurposes that is required for public enterprise is to assist in stabilising employment, which it has done time and time again in periods of difficulty. Public enterprise has done that and will do it again. It provides reliable services to private enterprise, the infrastructure base upon which private enterprise is able to work and trade successfully, both in Australia and overseas. One of the reasons we provide public enterprises is to underpin what we are doing in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: They are the things that do not happen to make a profit, cannot make a profit, yet are basic requirements for making a profit. We need to look at whether or not we are dealing with the fact-as the Liberal Party would want us to believe-that the public sector is intrinsically inefficient. It is an interesting proposition that in the recent Royal Commission on the Economic Union and Development Prospects for Canada, Messrs Borins and Boardman reached the following conclusion in their submission which was based on a review of recent studies of public enterprise efficiency:

Firstly, there is no consistent evidence that public enterprise is inherently less efficient than private enterprise. At least in mature industries, both in Canada and abroad, public and private firms tend to have comparable performance levels when examined on an industry by industry basis.

Secondly, the environment of Crown corporations appears to be a stronger determinant of efficiency than the mere fact of public ownership. In particular, Crown corporations in competitive environments appear to perform as efficiently as their private sector counterparts. Langford concludes: `The results of modern studies clearly render anachronistic the traditional hypothesis that a change in ownership from public to private is bound to increase efficiency.'

That is an interesting exercise from people who, unlike the rabble that have been actually dissembling themselves in the chamber today, have attempted to look at the studies that have been made on these items. Whether or not those studies will actually hold up remains to be seen, but at least somebody has taken the trouble to undertake some surveys, investigations and research, and then sought to review that type of research in a coherent and rational form. I think it is interesting when one does that outside the ideological humbug that goes on in this type of debate that inevitably one is drawn to the conclusion, as I have just read out, that what indeed matters, as anyone with a knowledge of business knows, is not so much the ownership, which is important, but the environment in which those particular industries exist and work.

We cannot use, as some people seem to suggest we should, the criterion of profitability, because some of our essential services are inherently loss-making. One of those is the primary and secondary education sector. On any table of income and expenditure it costs a fortune. But anybody who knows anything about the role of education in our society would say, `Hang on; you are not counting all the factors. You should not just count the dollars and cents that come in and go out on a particular enterprise. You actually have to count the worth to the community of having primary and secondary education'. That is the crux of the argument that I am putting. We cannot just count the dollars in, dollars out. We have to work out what value that particular enterprise has to the general community. Someone might say, `In Australia we have a vibrant private sector'. What we do have in Australia is a non-profit making private sector, most of which is 95 per cent recurrent funds supported out of taxpayers' funds. It is a non-profit sector and in that sense it is not part of the private sector so-called.

There has been interesting debate on some of the enterprises, but the institution which people feel quite happy to attack on as many occasions as possible is Telecom Australia. Telecom is a very interesting body. We have the very interesting cross-subsidisation exercise whereby city subscribers assist those in the country and business subscribers assist those who are private and present services subsidise future services.

When we look at the sell-off of British Telecom an interesting fact emerges. There were 2.1 million original shareholders. That figure shrank to 1.7 million in 10 days. In 1986, the employees-remember that was the big thing at the time; employees were going to own it, and that was why it was all right to do it-held less than 5 per cent of the shares in British Telecom. Anyone who knew the private stock market would have realised that that was inevitable. The whole exercise was a pure furphy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The underwriters skimmed off 5 per cent of the take.

—That is true. There has been a 1,000 per cent increase in the charge for a local call from a public telephone box, and domestic subscribers now have to pay for what formerly were free services. Why is that? It is because we have removed the cross-subsidisation. Senator Alston was quite happy for the country people to pay more for Telecom. It is the country people who will suffer if the rabble on my right ever come to government and privatise Telecom. Public enterprises in Australia have been efficient. They are an incredibly important part of the economy. They need the support of the community because they assist in making our society the type of society it is-the best in the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a matter of public importance-namely, the Government's sell-out of Australian consumers and taxpayers by its craven capitulation to the trade unions and party machine on the privatisation issue. At the outset I take the opportunity of saying to Senator Macklin that I regret his intemperate outburst directed at me during his remarks which clearly was based upon a mishearing of what I had said. The only alternative explanation would be that he was misrepresenting me. I am not prepared to assume that he was. My interjection was to the effect that the private sector in this country provides jobs. How that can be regarded as an attack upon private sector profits, which is what Senator Macklin presented me as saying, is beyond me.

SPEECH.PARA: I regard this debate as comforting. What we are debating in essence is the power of ideas. I have watched the idea that we need to get rid of protection policy being debated for the last 20 years in this country. I am glad to say that it now appears to be an idea whose time has come. It is an idea which even Senator Button has begun embracing to the extent of dipping at least a tiny toe-that is not a personal reflection upon Senator Button, I hasten to add-into the water. Next week's economic statement from the Government may begin to show some evidence that the time of the idea of getting rid of protection in this country has come.

In the same way, when a few years ago a few other people and I began the H. R. Nicholls Society, directed towards provoking a debate in this country upon the need to address the most important single reform which is required for Australia's future today, namely, the deregulation of the labour market, we were reviled from every part of the left-hand side of politics. Indeed, a good many in the centre and somewhat on the other side were a little uneasy at some of the things we were then saying. I make no bones about that. We were assailed by people like Ms Pamela Williams, who wrote a famous article in the Business Review Weekly entitled, `The Union Busters'. At the time we were set upon by the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who described us as `political illiterates' and `economic troglodytes'. We were assailed by the then Hon. Mick Young on the Channel 9 Sunday program in August 1986, who referred to the `sinister spokesman for the New Right'. In other words, we were subjected to the usual and absolutely foreseeable tired McCarthyism of the Left which is what the Australian Labor Party and this Government always put forward when they do not like what is being said from the other side of the chamber or the other side of the political spectrum. I will not spend further time talking about the contribution to that debate of such nowadays Labor party notables as Mr John Halfpenny, Mr Laurie Carmichael, the chief author of Australia Reconstructed, and people of that ilk. However, I remark that the kind of smear campaigns which were running rife at that time were characteristic of the sources from which they emanated.

But what has come of it? Today almost everyone except the Labor Party recognises that our regulated labour market has to be freed. We have to deregulate or perish. The time has not yet come for that idea to be adopted, but it is well and truly on the way. The same can be said for that matter that is under discussion this afternoon-privatisation. Less than three years ago, in 1985, proposals for privatisation were put forward in the South Australian election campaign by the leader of the Liberal Party in South Australia. Those proposals were supported at the time by Mr John Howard, who I think had then recently become leader of the Federal Liberal Party. They were bitterly, mercilessly and intellectually shamefully attacked--

TALK.START.PARA: —Dishonestly.

—Dishonestly-I thank the honourable senator-not just by the Premier of South Australia but by the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and, of course, not least, the South Australian Public Service trade unions. So it was with some surprise that almost immediately after the Federal election last July we saw our Prime Minister launching into a vigorous campaign to persuade his Party and his old mates in the trade union movement that privatisation was a good idea, a great idea, after all.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, we have come to understand a little more about the capacity of the Prime Minister to change his mind on these issues. In passing, I note the incredible headline of an article in the Australian of last Saturday in which Mr Paul Kelly told us all about the dilemma that Mr Hawke was facing in that he did not know whether to keep his promise about the gold tax. That was confirmed by the omission, so to speak, this week by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). Why have we seen this volte-face by the Prime Minister and some of his key Ministers at this time? I suggest that what we have seen has been born out of a spirit of desperation on the part of a number of the key Ministers in this Government who are sufficiently economically rational to understand that they will never succeed in addressing effectively the economic problems of this country until the Government begins to deal with the problem of trade union power in this country. Obviously they cannot do anything directly about the trade union bosses because, of course, the trade union bosses have a far too powerful position within the constitution and, above all, the finances of the Labor Party.

So this cabal of centrally located and very influential and powerful Ministers has cast about for means of doing something indirectly. That is why we have been hearing a bit more about cutting tariffs and about privatisation. That is why the Treasurer (Mr Keating) persuaded the Prime Minister to transfer to him, the Treasurer, responsibility for the Industries Assistance Commission without, I may say, consulting Senator Button who had previously been responsible for this body. That is why, as I say, the Prime Minister has suddenly swung around 180 degrees and charged off in pursuit of the privatisation of public enterprises.

This Government knows, as we do, that it is the government business undertakings in this country which are at the heart of the power of the trade union movement. After all, it is a matter of public record that, in the private sector, only-I should perhaps not say only-35 per cent of the members of the work force are members of trade unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is about double for the public sector.

—As Senator Alston quite rightly points out, in the public sector it is about 75 per cent, about double that figure. Eighty five per cent of Australians want to break down trade union power. For years now every public opinion poll taken in this country has shown that between 80 and 85 per cent of the people believe that trade union power is excessive. If we want to break down trade union power, particularly by stealth and particularly from a position of supposed alliance with these people-of course, much more than this is needed but it is useful to make a start in this as in all things-we should begin to do it by cutting protection and privatising government business enterprises. That is precisely what this Government had set out to do in next week's economic statement. Indeed, I think it will deliver some part of it at least in relation to industrial protection, although of a diminished kind. Here again, the trade union bosses have told the Government that it must not do as much as it originally wanted to do. But the trade union bosses are not altogether stupid. Yesterday they told Senator Evans to stop it or he would go blind.
—And he did.

—He has been blind for some time. Senator Evans turned up at a meeting of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) Executive held on the Gold Coast like a schoolboy to be chastened and confess his sins. At the end of the conference he was sent out of the room to issue publicly his mea culpa--
—Mea maxima culpa.

—Mea maxima culpa; I thank Senator Alston. That public personal seppuku-the Japanese term for disembowelling-having been done, Mr Simon Crean, the President of the ACTU, emerged from the media conference to tell us that the privatisation debate was finished. `Privatisation is dead', he said. We read on the front page of the Australian newspaper this morning, `Evans admits defeat'. The more parochial reader of newspapers in this town who prefers the Canberra Times would have seen the headline `Evans concedes defeat in privatisation debate'.
—Gareth kicked to death.

—Senator Alston reminds me that `Gareth kicked to death' would be another suitable headline. Notwithstanding the interest of such headlines, Mr Crean is wrong. Characteristically, he is suffering from the delusion that the views of the trade union bosses are the same as those of the majority of Australians. The privatisation debate is not finished; it is just that the trade union bosses have told Senator Evans and his colleagues to stop pursuing it. That is not the same thing at all. I notice that in this debate-I have only a couple of minutes left for my contribution-the speakers on the Government side, apart from the hapless Senator Evans, who fled the chamber after delivering his impassioned diatribe, have been Senator Bolkus and Senator Collins. We also had a contribution from the Australian Democrats which, as usual, might as well have been delivered from the Labor Party side of the House, but I leave that aside. The real question is: Where is Senator Walsh; where is the Minister for Finance? After all he is the Minister who has general responsibility for the financial policy of public enterprises. In a major speech less than three weeks ago Senator Walsh described the views of those of his colleagues in the Australian Labor Party who have been battling against him in this matter as three great lies. Senator Walsh said:

SPEECH.PARA: There are also the three great lies of the current debate on public and private ownership: public enterprise operates in the public interest; that the Government has benefited financially from its public enterprise investments . . .

The third great lie really had more to do with the internal workings of the Labor Party; I will not bore the Senate with that. Senator Walsh went on to illustrate his remarks very effectively by saying that it is a gross error simply to assume that public enterprise operates in the public interest when too often it operates in its own organisational interests and the interests of its management and employees.

I believe that Senator Evans's craven capitulation yesterday to the people who control the Labor Party-that is to say, Simon Crean and the trade union bosses-is comparable with the famous episode in this town some years ago when Mr Calwell and Mr Whitlam waited outside the doors of the National Executive of the Labor Party for the 12 faceless men to allow them to have something to say about the future control of their own party. What we saw yesterday at the Gold Coast is an identical situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —One wonders why at the moment the Australian public has such a cynical assessment of politicians, and one wonders how Senator Stone can talk about public opinion and put on a performance such that he spent 14 minutes of his speech criticising personalities and for the last 60 seconds tried to get to the guts of the issue in question. One can understand that cynicism. One can also understand that cynicism when this great crusader for the private sector is known by all to have been a parasite on the public sector for over 25 years of his life. He talks about the need to deregulate and lower tariffs. Who was it who, in the mid-1970s, as Secretary to the Treasury, strenuously fought almost to the death against a reduction in tariffs? It was Senator Stone himself.

SPEECH.PARA: What about this cynicism? We have here today an Opposition that knows only one thing-negativism. Members of the Opposition oppose at all costs. They showed to the electorate a great example this week of that sort of negativism on the constitutional referenda. The Opposition Leader, Mr Howard, who has trouble agreeing with his own party let alone with the National Party, reached great heights of irrationality this week. Earlier this year he actually wrote to a council in his electorate advocating support for a referendum which would entrench local government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I can understand the Minister's acute embarrassment but the subject matter before the Chair relates to the privatisation of public assets. It has nothing to do whatever with referendum questions, and I ask that the Minister confine himself to the matter at hand.
—Order! This has been a wide ranging debate on both sides of the chamber. I am listening to what Senator Bolkus is saying. At this moment I believe there is no point of order.

—I was linking the Opposition's approach on this issue to its general approach, an approach that has been rejected by the electorate. On the one hand, John Howard, the Opposition Leader, says he supports local government being entrenched in the Constitution and, on the other hand, he says he will campaign against it. There has been no change of mind, according to John Howard. His explanation is that he wrote the letter to his local council as the honourable member for Bennelong and he has taken the other position in his capacity as Leader of the Opposition. We now have a schizophrenic Opposition Leader-one who cannot even agree with himself. That underscores the sort of opposition we are getting in this place. It is locked in ideological rigidity. It has never come up with a comprehensive strategy, not only over the last two or three years but also right through the time it was in government. It is a strategy, an ideology, on which it was soundly beaten in South Australia, in Western Australia and federally.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the Opposition's great god, Thatcher. What about the Thatcherite commitment to the sale of public assets. It failed because it did not confront the basic issues that the Opposition refused to face in this debate and in the debate that has been going on generally in Australia. Even Friedmanites believe that the British program has failed, because it never really addressed issues of competition and consumer interest and national industry and economic objectives. On the other hand, what has been presented in this place is a recognition by the Labor Party and the labour movement that the public sector does provide a service.

No-one here from the National Party of Australia would disagree with the extent of cross-subsidisation by the public sector. It provides a service interwoven with the private sector. I refer to the degree of research provided by public institutions. Telecom Australia buys 90 per cent of its purchases from local industry. We recognise that there is a need for a continuing, viable and active public sector. We have been committed to a serious and sensible debate about where public sector policy should go. The two issues in the matter of public importance presented today show the great differences between the parties. The wording assumes that selling public enterprises will always benefit consumers. I mentioned the Thatcher experiment. After privatisation of telecommunications in the United Kingdom service to consumers declined so dramatically that Oftel, in July 1987, threatened to fine the new privatised British Telecom if service did not improve. Oftel figures showed that in 1987 in the UK 48 per cent of public phone box users had difficulty finding one phone box that worked.

Since November 1984 the typical local residential consumers' call charge increased in the UK by 20 per cent and typical business calls decreased in price by 12 per cent. So clearly the benefits are not automatic. It is not just a case of blind ideology. The assumption by the Opposition, by conservative forces, is that private enterprises are necessarily more efficient. That is simply not the case. Senator Stone did not even try to address it. There is no empirical evidence to support that contention. In fact, whichever study has been done on this point has resulted in an inconclusive finding or a finding that the public sector is not less efficient than the private sector.

In 1982 a study surveyed Canada, Switzerland, the United States of America and Australia. It found that private sector operations were less efficient. Another survey in 1982, by Richard Pryke, was inconclusive. What we forget when we are locked in blind ideological debate in this place is that the market does not necessarily always allocate the best. We forget about monopolies, externalities and current, as opposed to future, demands. What about things such as the unequal distribution of wealth? Does that really prevent inefficiencies or present consumers with the best choice? There is no blind ideological response to that. It is a very intricate question that needs to be addressed. We should look at the public sector in relation to the National Party and the extent of rural subsidies. The private sector works well because of the interwoven relationship with the public sector. This Government has to confront the Opposition's response, which is locked blindly into ideology with the great issues that have to be approached such as capital formation, efficiency and accountability.

What has been the record of the Liberal Party's response on these matters? What about the serious question of developing a comprehensive and reasoned policy on the public sector? This is the first Government in Australia's history to take on the challenge of developing such a policy. Certainly the conservatives have never addressed it; they have continually messed around with ad hoc approaches to public enterprises. Let us look at their responses to the public sector in the long years of conservative rule when Senator Stone was in positions of power and influence that he now does not have. Their response was to introduce a whole lot of ad hoc controls. They included financial supervision by the Treasurer-and I suppose, in turn, the Secretary to the Treasury-the Auditor-General, the Public Accounts Committee and the portfolio Minister. They responded with personnel supervision from the Public Service Board and associated other mechanisms. They supervised capital expenditure by all sorts of mechanisms. This is not to mention general scrutiny by departmental representatives and so on. What they locked the public sector into was a web of administrative arrangements that led to appalling consequences for strategic planning and for competition. That is the way they responded. The serious issues are not those issues that have been addressed by the Opposition. As I said, its ad hoc responses when in government led to the situation we are in now.

Another response has been well exemplified by what happened in the Menzies era with Trans Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia. Conservatives have always skimmed off profits from public enterprises and starved them of capital. How is it possible to have a level playing field when one lot of players have their hands tied behind their backs? The Opposition claims to support competition but every time a public enterprise has been able to compete successfully it has been stymied in its competitive approach. Let us look at the situation of Australian Airlines. As Trans Australia Airlines it was going well; it was competing extremely well. What happened? Menzies forced fleet equalisation onto TAA and drew it back. Over the next 20 years Ansett was allowed to expand its capital base and improve its regional operations and networks, all under the protection of the two-airline agreement under Menzies. TAA was controlled in its fleet purchases and so on. It entered the 1980s with capital of only $15m.

It is those sorts of legacies that this Government is now facing, but facing them not in an ideologically fixed way. The Government is committed to stating clearly what our objectives are for the public sector and for individual enterprises. We are committed to giving public enterprises the operational flexibility to achieve these objectives. We are committed to reforming the range of performance measures on which such enterprises can be assessed so that strategic planning can proceed on a sound, rational basis. This is the result of several years of steady, rational work in this area.

What has been the greatest measure introduced in this Parliament in terms of the public sector and its operations? It was Senator Walsh's report on policy guidelines for Commonwealth statutory bodies and government business enterprises, tabled last year. It took a few years of work, but that sort of response is a bit hard for the bovver boys of the Right to accept. It took a few years of work. It provided a comprehensive basis for reform. It provided for corporate plans to state enterprise objectives clearly. That is the sort of comprehensive approach to reform that distinguishes our approach from the approach of Senator Alston's Party.

It has to be recognised that the public sector in Australia is small-small compared to the public sectors of other countries, small compared to the public sectors of Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries. It has to be recognised for the contribution it makes to the private sector. It has to be recognised that the public sector here operates within a web of ad hoc constraints. We have to recognise in addressing this issue that the private sector really could not develop without the infrastructure provided by public investment-whether it be roads, rail networks, water, gas, telecommunications and so on. Basically, it provides the underpinning of our system.

I will not say much more, but in finishing my contribution to the debate I will quote from someone about whom Senator Alston thought a lot in the past. That person said, `Public bodies have an important part to play in our national development because many things we do are too big in scope or too important for private people or even groups of people to undertake alone'. That was said on 22 February 1956 by Malcolm Fraser.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the things that are most striking about the contribution from the Government side in this debate is the suggestion coming through that there are ideologues in the debate and that they all reside on the conservative side of politics. Of course, that is just another canard, one that is perpetrated endlessly by the majority of those unthinking members on the other side. Let me begin by quoting from a recent article in the Australian which reported a very important speech by Senator Walsh. Senator Walsh said that ideology would ground asset sales. He was reported as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Substantial savings from further large assets sale in the next Budget are unlikely in the wake of `ideological' opposition within the Labor Party to privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank, Qantas and Australian Airlines
But he said debate over privatisation would prevent any further large assets sales in the next Budget because of the length of time needed to set up the necessary machinery.
Although he welcomed the debate on privatisation, he said it should be conducted on a case-by-case basis rather than on ideological grounds.

Never a truer word was said. The opposition to privatisation comes almost exclusively from those with a vested interest in the subject, or those who believe they represent them. Indeed, the fundamentalists, the true conservatives in the economic debate in this country on privatisation, reside squarely on the Labor side of politics. I regard that as a tragedy because all of the leading economic players in the Government fully appreciate the significance of efficiency and of ensuring that public enterprise is able to deliver at the lowest cost. Where it cannot, then its responsibilities can be transferred to the private sector. Mr Hawke said that almost 12 months ago.

What has happened since then? We have had a number of tentative efforts by various spokesmen to try somehow to drag the Labor Party screaming and yelling into the twentieth century. But no, the latest abject capitulation by Senator Evans is just one in a long line of sorry cave-ins. In an article headed `Hawke throws down gauntlet on privatisation', it is stated:

Mr Hawke is understood to have argued strongly for the need to allow the Government flexibility on the question of privatisation and to have urged the unions to explain the Government's position on the issue to their members.
Without a change of policy at the conference, the privatisation of Australian Airlines, Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank-which are on Mr Hawke's hit list-will be blocked.

The Government even went so far as to try to threaten some of the sacred cows of left wing ideologues. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) did so only a matter of a couple of months ago. According to a newspaper article:

Mr Hawke indicated in a rare extended news conference that aged care, education and training and lower taxation could all be casualties of the failure of the party to accept the Government's sell-off proposals.

It is perfectly clear that the economic rationalists at the top echelons of the Government are acutely aware of the capital funding crisis that is besetting not just Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines and the Commonwealth Bank, but a whole range of public trading enterprises. There are many myths around. One is that we cannot privatise something that is making a loss. Let me tell honourable senators that Japan National Railways, which was a chronic income loser for very many years, has been successfully privatised to the extent that it was carved up into six separate companies together with a freight company. In the first year they all made profits.

Privatised companies will bring in increased revenue to government. That is quite clear. The rate of return on capital is something like four or five times higher in the private sector than it is in the public sector. One gets different figures, but the rate of return is estimated to be anywhere between about 1 and 2 1/2 per cent on public enterprises compared to something like 12 to 13 per cent on private enterprises. It is a fact that is inescapable and it is a fact that is very well known to those who sit on bodies such as the Structural Adjustment Committee. That is why it is such a tragedy.

Let us just look at a minor example. We see on the cellular mobile telephones issue that poor old hapless Senator Evans-I will not say hopeless-put the issue up and was able to persuade all his senior colleagues; but no, he got hauled in with Mr Peter Morris, another Minister, and what happened? They got kicked to death-7 : 4 against-and poor old Senator Evans then had to go back to the Structural Adjustment Committee, apologise profusely, say that he had been rolled and could he please have permission to change. As a result, when we get the May economic statement next Wednesday, we will find that there will be no liberalisation of that particular market. Although it is exploding and worth about $2 billion in the United States, and had something like 300,000 new subscribers in the last financial year-it is a growth area of the greatest potential-nothing is going to happen in this country. There will be a review in a couple of years time. It is a bit like all those other areas where the Government knows in its heart of hearts that it is a good thing, but it cannot quite bring itself to bite the bullet.

Let me read to the Senate a classic example not only of monumental arrogance but of the way in which the Labor Party's blinkered approach to this whole issue proceeds irrespective of the public interest. This is what Senator Evans, the sell-off king who has just admitted defeat, had to say on 16 November 1987, about six months ago. Addressing an August confer- ence on privatisation in Australia, he said:

. . . I hope you will forgive me saying that the only privatisation debate that really matters in Australia at the moment is the one that will take place in the Australian Labor Party in the run up to the next National Conference in June 1988.

Unless the Party Platform is modified at that Conference, no matter what amount of rational debate or argument occurs anywhere else, and no matter how the pros and cons may weigh up in any individual case, no significant government business enterprise will be sold, in whole or part, to the private sector.

Madam Acting Deputy President, can you imagine a more craven capitulation than that? The extent of the incapacity of the Government to extend the debate into the wider community, the admission that it is wholly and solely a captive of the trade union movement and the Labor organisation, is a tragedy for the public interest. I suggest that Senator Evans should face up to the inexorable logic of the case and insist that there be a public inquiry. That is what is required. But no; what he told the Australian Council of Trade Unions yesterday was that he now proposed the formation of a balanced party committee, with trade unions, parliamentarians and extra-parliamentary representatives from within the Party. It is an absolute disgrace. We will have more and more navel gazing, going absolutely nowhere, defying any concept of public interest.

Only a few days ago we heard from Mr Keating-another victim of the abject cave-in by the so-called Labor strong man. He knows that the Commonwealth Bank is in desperate need of capital funds. He knows, as we all do from the Caucus paper circulated by Senator Evans, that there is a range of enterprises that need funding, but probably no need is more critical than that of the Commonwealth Bank. Mr Keating has refused to circulate his Caucus paper until after the May economic statement. But he has already thrown in the towel, because yesterday he said that he had postponed indefinitely any thought of partial privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank. It is pretty wimpish stuff on the part of this man who would like to pride himself on his economic toughness. I do not suppose that he has ever thought of himself as a man of principle, but again this shows the primacy of politics in the Australian Labor Party. It will never let a policy get in the way of good political advantage.

It is clear that once again the national interest has been cynically sacrificed on the altar of expediency. For more than 12 months we have been standing by watching a number of public trading enterprises bleeding to death. All that has gone on is this navel gazing on the part of the Labor Party. There is not a thought of the public interest; not a thought of how the debate might be widened, how rational considerations might be brought to bear and what the community interest really might be. Again, all we have is another pathetic suggestion that there be some sort of broadened internal debate.

Senator Evans was laughing as he told the Senate today that we place emphasis on careful policy development. It is a pathetic charade; it is a tragedy and a travesty of sensible and rational debate. He said that it is a fast moving policy environment. It might be, but there are a lot of dinosaurs who have stood absolutely still for the last 12 months. Clearly that is because they do not want to face up to the consequences of efficiency in the public sector. The Government knows that we are not talking about dismantling every aspect of the public sector. We are not talking about selling off every public trading enterprise.
