We are talking about a rational and sensible assessment of the capital needs of those trading enterprises and looking at how their functions can best be performed. Probably no one said it better in terms of concept-but, as usual, very poorly in terms of expression-than the Prime Minister nearly 12 months ago. He said that the onus is on those who wish to keep these enterprises in the public sector to demonstrate why they can be more efficiently dealt with in that arena. That is absolutely right.

I suggest that it is very difficult to discharge the onus of proof. Very few of these enterprises will be more efficiently managed in the public sector. That is because, as both Senator Walsh and Senator Button confirmed in Question Time today, they have their own agendas. They are not out there as paragons of national virtue. They are not concerned about what the public interest might be. They are ordinary human beings like all of us who think of themselves first. They have their own constituencies and they are worried about what the consequences might be in terms of industrial relations if they suddenly recognise the virtues of competition and deregulation. As Senator Walsh said, it is a naive assumption by advocates of public ownership that organisations which are publicly owned will operate in the public interest. We are not trying to force morality on them. All we are saying is that if one is in a competitive environment, one's mind will be concentrated on the things that count. In private enterprise that is called the bottom line and it has a lot going for it. It enables one to structure one's thoughts to deliver efficiency and ultimately to provide those services that are very necessary in a whole range of areas.

One of the great tragedies-it is understandable why Senator Walsh calls the Australian Democrats the fairies at the bottom of the garden party-is that the Democrats persistently and wilfully misunderstand the notion of cross-subsidisation. There are many areas where it will not be possible to price services at cost and expect the consumers to pay for them. In that situation there is absolutely no reason why we cannot have a direct and transparent public subsidy from the government purse if it is justified. That is a political decision and a matter of judgment. It could be done by way of an internal levy. As in the case of British Telecom, it could be made a requirement of that organisation's licence. In Japan, NTT does not even worry about cross-subsidies; it gets on with the business because it is big enough to be able to carry the extent of the cross-subsidisation.

I can tell the Senate that Senator Evans is very annoyed indeed because he believes that Telecom Australia has misled him about the extent of cross-subsidisation within Telecom and he will be giving it quite a bucket in the May statement, unless he is forced to take the words out before next Wednesday. He is very annoyed that Telecom's ambit claim of up to $2,500m of cross-subsidisation may well be a matter of $300m or $400m. There is a phenomenal difference, but it is a very interesting political position to take. It is one that frightens the horses and those startled fawns in the Democrats. It is a tragedy that those misunderstandings and misconstructions can distract attention from the reality of the debate, which is that we can continue to deliver services to rural and remote areas if we are prepared to pay for them, but we should not expect that that should necessarily operate, or should operate at all, by way of cross-subsidisation.

We are about competition and efficiency. We are concerned not to be ideologues who believe in a nightwatchman approach and a laissez-faire economy. We believe in efficiency, as do Senators Walsh and Button, Messrs Dawkins and Keating and the Prime Minister. The difference is that we are prepared to say where we stand. We are prepared to stand up for our principles, to announce our policies in a whole range of areas and to accept the consequences that flow. But no, we have this doubletalk and double standards on the other side. Those opposite know in their heart of hearts what is right, but they are not allowed by Mr Crean and others to face up to those realities. They are simply told that it is not on. It is not on because it is not politically saleable to those who do not want to know. Paul Kelly calls them ALP traditionalists. I would have thought that `fundamentalists' was a more accurate word. Unfortunately, the end result is the same: they do not want to be told; they do not want to understand the facts of life and they do not want to understand that privatisation is a policy that has swept the world, not just industrialised countries. Many Third World countries beat a track to the door of the British asking for advice on how to implement privatisation policy. It is a policy that works. It is working in the United Kingdom. The British have already chalked up #25 billion worth of sales and they will double that over the next few years. There will always be problems and teething difficulties. Quality of service is the latest. But in no way does that affect the quality of the issue and the quality of the decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the things that today's debate has brought home to me is that it must be a dreadful thing being a conservative backbencher.
—You will get your chance.

—To be a conservative backbencher? With respect, Senator, I do not think so. The matter of public importance accuses the Government of being captive of the trade union movement and the party machine on the privatisation issue. On other issues this week the Leader of the Liberal Party has tried to exert his non-leadership by trying to gag members of his own Party on important issues. The reality in the Australian Labor Party is that its entire back bench and front bench are jointly involved on this issue as they are on all issues. I am a member of two Caucus committees that have been dealing directly with this issue for some time. The issue has been around in the Labor Party in a real sense for only about six months, since it was launched by Senator Evans last year. The debate has been intense, stimulating and ongoing.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney, when he opened the debate, said that the Opposition had offered its bipartisan support to the Government on privatisation. Being offered bipartisan support by the Opposition would be somewhat akin to being offered swimming lessons by a crocodile. Senator Alston talked about the great benefit to the Government of opening up the debate in this fashion because of the rational nature that the debate would then have. I must say with some feeling that the debate has given me an extraordinary insight into the operations of the Opposition's back bench. It is quite extraordinary.

Honourable senators opposite came into the chamber today armed with pieces of paper, which they hid under their desks, then held up on a signal, like a bunch of pavlovian dogs. If anyone in the public gallery had done exactly the same thing, that person would have been thrown out, no doubt with the full support of those opposite. That was an extraordinary insight into the level of the contribution made to this important debate by those opposite. I can say without fear or favour--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a pretty good headline that they produced, was it not?

—Whether it was or not, if the Government Whip, a Minister or anyone else-and I have this amazing vision of this bunch of parliamentarians being lined up in the party room next to the photocopier, being armed with the placards by the Whip and being told to hold them up when the whistle was blown-had given me a piece of paper and said, `You take this into the chamber and when we blow the whistle, hold it up', I would have told him what to do with that piece of paper. What happened today gave an extraordinary insight into the real attitude on this important matter that is being debated today. From whom does one have bipartisan support? From whom does one accept the offer? One thing that this week's events have shown very clearly is that it is in fact Senator John Stone who is running the Opposition in this Parliament. There is no question about that. I give full marks to Senator Stone. This week he has rolled John Howard on three very important and substantive issues: taxation, the referendum and, only in the past few days, an issue very important to me at least-a matter that would have been the subject of the first resolution passed in the new Parliament, a mild and utterly qualified motion drafted by Father Frank Brennan. To the credit of those opposite, Father Brennan had met with the Leader of the Opposition due to the assistance of some honourable senators opposite who had organised it and had the full support of Senator Chaney. Mr Howard had suggested some changes to the motion, which were effected. With his full support, that was going to be passed in the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things I like about Senator Stone is that at least one knows where one stands with him. I prefer to deal with people like that. Senator Stone was quite forthright in the meeting that Father Brennan had with him. He said to Father Brennan, `I will fight this tooth and nail in the party room and I will win'. And he did. So in one week the Leader of the Opposition has been rolled on three very substantial matters by Senator Stone. So it is absolutely clear who is running the Federal Opposition at the moment. Good luck to him. Senator Chaney has an interesting mannerism. When he addresses the chamber he consistently turns his back on the Government and the President and addresses his own troops. If I had Senator Stone sitting behind me, I would be frightened to turn my back on him as well.

Unfortunately, in the 60 seconds before the conclusion of this debate I cannot address another important issue in detail. But I draw the attention of all honourable senators to the Press which is available and to the analyses that have been done on experience overseas with privatisation. I am an absolute supporter of the full review and investigation of what is and what is not possible in this area. I commend the Labor Party for commencing this important debate and for continuing it. In the same rational and sensible fashion as the Labor Party has turned around the economic life of this country from recession just five short years ago to the economic prosperity we enjoy today, it will also succeed on this issue.
